elements.text: [Part One]
Big explosion reverberates.
Beautiful.

(aristocratic lady) I'd invested all my family's money into research into a cure. The funds were just pouring away. Every line of research was a blind alley. We started experimenting with the benefits of zero gravity for treatment. We took patients up into an orbital satellite I'd bought off a government. Oh, they were always keen to take my money. Ridiculed me in public, but took my money behind closed doors.
And the Koteem contacted you.
They did.
Screams, sirens, knife slashes
Stop it! Let go of me! Ah! Please!
(Inside a large moving diesel-powered ground vehicle. The Doctor groans.)
Nyssa. Nyssa?
It's all right. I was just getting you a hot drink.
Oh, thanks. Mmm. You let me sleep.
You needed to.
Hmm, perhaps. How long was I?
Not that long. Quain says we still have four days to go.
Oh. How are you feeling?
Well, I've felt better.
Me too. What's the matter?
Do you think we're doing the right thing?
The right thing?
Going along with Quain and his people.
Now there's a question. What exactly is the right thing?
I'm assuming that's one of your rhetorical questions.
That's often the trouble, isn't it?
What is?
That question. There's never really one answer. Mmm. Got any more of that?
Yes, here.
Pours liquid.
It's good, isn't it.
Mmm.
Just about the only remotely pleasant thing we've encountered on this planet.
Possibly.
Possibly? Definitely, I'd say
Yes, I might agree with you, but that would just be our point of view.
You're being very philosophical.
Am I? Hmm, yes, well, it's all a matter of perspective, isn't it.
Is it? I'm not sure I follow you.

Well, when you think about it, there are a lot of different perspectives on this planet, aren't there? Points of view. Deeply held convictions. What the security people think, what Quain and his people think, whatever it is the Koteem think.
Are you saying we should never have got involved?
It's certainly a point of view.
Doctor, we didn't have a choice.
Maybe we didn't.
Maybe we did?
I did.
You're in a very peculiar mood, Doctor.
Maybe it's just a question of survival.
Do you mean for the Veln, or the Koteem?
Or us.
Do you think we're still in danger?
I think the sooner we get to the Tardis and leave, the better.
A man sighs. Knock on door.
Come.
Door opens, telephone ringing heard in background.
Have you got the tapes?
Er, yes, sir.
Well, let's not arse about.
Door closes.
I want to get to the bottom of this.
Of course.
Sit. Stick the tape in. I take it you're going to talk me through this? I don't want to sit through hours of the stuff. Just give me the highlights and the headlines.
I have prepared a report.
Report? (laughs) Always so present and correct, aren't you, Brodlik.
I pride myself

On all the fancy letters after your name, yeah, I know. Didn't help you this time, though, did they? If it weren't for the fact that I've got the Security Minister breathing down my neck about all this, I might take time to enjoy making you squirm. But since I'm Head of Security, and you're supposedly one of my most respected underlings, my arse is very much roasting over the fire as we speak, so get on with it!
May I?
Fiddles with tape.
Oh, I'll be taping this on my machine.
I see.
Any objection? Wouldn't want to miss any of your words of wisdom, would we? Make sure you speak up for the sake of the microphone. Name and rank. That'd be a nice place to start, don't you think?
Beep.
Security Department Senior Psychiatric Interrogator Leslar Brodlik reporting to Chief of Security Rolf Gilbrook. Subject, alien incursion.
By the Koteem.
Er, that isn't certain.
What do you mean?
If you'll permit me to continue, sir.
You'd better start making sense soon, Brodlik.
Well, you'll be the judge of that, I'm sure, Chief.
Very much so.
Tape rolling.
This is my first interview with the prisoner, and
Pause. She is a beauty, isn't she?
Apart from the bruising to the right eye. Overzealous restraint in the custody processing.
Oh, my custody boys love their job.
Yes. I believe you did mention that when you handed me this case.
Yes. Never mind that. Just get on with it.
On the tape, papers are turned.
[OC]: Your custody record gives your name as Nyssa Traken. Is that correct? Do you understand me?
[OC]: Yes. Yes, I understand.
May I have something to drink? My mouth's very dry.
The hospital discharged you after only three days. They said you were recovered. Are you feeling ill?
Only if you count being beaten up by your thugs as illness.
You resisted arrest, I believe.
I didn't get a chance. And I didn't say my name was Nyssa Traken. I said it was Nyssa of Traken. Now can I have something to drink, please?
Yes, there's telse in the flask. Help yourself.
Er, oh, thank you.
Smoke?
What?
Pours liquid.
Er, no. If you don't mind, I don't do that.
Strange. I think I will.
Strikes match.
Why is it strange?
(exhales slowly) I believe I'm the one who asks questions. You understand the seriousness of the charge?
I understand that your thugs jumped to conclusions and didn't give me a chance to speak.
Some might say that was understandable given the circumstances.
Understandable?
You've been sent to me because you made certain assertions at the time of your custody processing. I'm the Senior Psychiatric Interrogator. I want to know why you said those things.
Psychiatric? You think I'm mad.
Er, you mentioned that you weren't from this planet, that you were just here on a short stop while the Dokter waited for the Tardis to er. and then the officer said you became very garbled.
I was suffering from a concussion. Your officers knocked me out. I'd only just regained consciousness when they started asking me questions.
The arresting officers report that you became violent at the scene of the crime.
As I recall, there were at least four arresting officers, all of them considerably bigger and stronger than me. The only violence came from them.
Do you wish to make an official complaint against these officers?
I wish to be released so that
So that you could return to the er, the Tardis. Who is this Dokter you mention?
He's a friend of mine.
[OC]: Oh? And where is he now?
[OC]: I don't know.
Pause it there.
Is there something?
This Doctor bloke. We got him on security cameras, didn't we?
Er, I believe so.
Wait a minute. They printed off a still for me. Ah, yes. This him?
Er, yes. Yes, I believe so.
If you'd got her to describe him in the first place, we could have had him picked up and you'd have saved us a lot of hassle.
My job was to determine Nyssa's mental condition and
Oh, on first name terms.
It's simply the prisoner's name. It's important to use their names to gain their trust.
Oh, yes, very diligent, Brodlik. All right, get on with it.
Perhaps I should move on to the next tape I've selected.
Did you have the medical report on her by the time
you did the first interview?
No. I was interrupted by the duty Medical Officer. I went to his office and looked over his reports, then returned to talk further with er, the prisoner.
Ah, I see. And what happened when you resumed the interview?
Er, well, the next day I was
No, no, not the next day. Play me the rest of the first day's tape. Just wind it on until after you got the medical report.
There isn't much of interest.
Play it!
[OC]: I'm sorry we were interrupted.
[OC]: When are you going to let me go?
I have your medical report here.
Oh yes, they took a blood sample from me. Rather brutally, as I remember.
Hmm. And the tests on your blood confirm that you are alien to Veln. You look surprised.
I thought
I would have presumed that you were aware you were not a native of this world.
Yes. It's just that
Yes?
I didn't know that people on this planet were aware of aliens.
Everyone knows of Koteem.
Koteem?
Your legacy is clear for all to see.
My legacy?
You claim not to know what your people did to this planet?
Let's assume I don't know what my people did.
Assume? I'm afraid I don't have time to play games. You're serious, aren't you.
So now you think I'm mad. But tell me anyway, Brodlik.
Tell you?
The legacy of the Koteem.
You're looking at it now. Oh, this is ridiculous.
What is? And what am I supposed to be looking at?
Me. You're looking at me, aren't you? And it's ridiculous that you'd think I believed you didn't know about the Koteem.
But you do believe me, don't you. You're a psychiatrist, a police psychiatrist. I think you Know when people are being less than honest.
All right, I'll play along. What do you see when you look at my face?
Er, I'm not sure what
Yes, I'm good at Knowing when people are being less than honest, and that's what you are being now. I'll make it easy for
you. You see ugliness when you look at my face. When you look at the face of most people in the world. Distorted skin tissue, abnormal bone structure. Not like your face. Not beautiful like you.
I
There are only a few of us, the impossibly rich, the elite few who indulge in cosmetic adjustments to make them look like, well, how the Veln looked once.
Once?
But you'd know all about that, wouldn't you.
Would I?
You were arrested on Forleon's estate, weren't you.
I, I don't know. Was I? I remember trees and grass. Flowers.
That'll be Forleon's estate, all right. There's nowhere else in this country like that.
No flowers?
Oh yes, of course, I forgot. You don't know anything. Didn't you look at the sky?
Sky?
(laughs) Oh, you're very good.
Good? I

But this is impossible. Of course you know what the Koteem did. The pollution in the sky. The clouds that we've had to stare at for four generations, dark blue at sunset and bright emerald in the midday summer sun.
Dyestrial pollution? And this race, the Koteem, they polluted your atmosphere? They caused
The genetic disfigurement. Yes, that's your people did.
But if they did this to you, why do they still come to your planet? Presumably they do, since you don't seem that surprised to find an alien here.
We know that you send agents to our world. Our security people have had to deal with a number of them.
Deal? And now that you're sure I'm a Koteem, you'll be handing me over to your security people. Or is there something stopping you?
There's nothing stopping me. I shall process your papers and hand you over.
Brodlik, I'm not a Koteem.
That's impossible. Your blood
My blood test showed I was not a native of this planet. Am I right?
Of course.
So it's tested against Veln blood.
Yes.
Was it tested against other Koteem samples?
I've no idea.
But you're thinking about it.
Tape stopped.
You should have handed her over to Security. Why didn't you?
By the time I'd
No, not later. At that point. The moment you were sure she was Koteem. You should have
I wasn't sure she
Oh. Now we get to it.
Get to what?
So what did you do?
I, I don't follow you. I
Shall I tell you what you did, Brodlik? You took matters into your own hands.
I had doubts. I wanted to, to check,

Check up on the blood test results? To quiz the Security Department's duty Medical Officer if you could? Yes, I know. That's bad enough in itself, but at this point, at the point when you left her in her comfortable little interview cell, what precisely did you do?
I'm not sure what you're trying to

Oh, Brodlik, Brodlik, Brodlik. I'm through playing games with you. Wake up! Haven't you got the message yet? This isn't an interview. You're not giving a report. You're in trouble. You went home, Brodlik. You went home early. I saw your face on the tape. You were a puzzled little Brodlik, weren't you? Oh, you psychiatric types. Always thought you were on the verge of being just as crazy as the nutters you deal with. Not very stable, are you? The pretty little alien girl rattled your cage, didn't she? And you went home early, all hot and bothered, to think about it, to plan what to do next for your cosy little case study. Never mind that you were breaking every major security regulation we have.
I had completed my allotted hours for that
And now you're lying! Dear me. You went home three hours early, back to your miserable little apartment.
(slightly muffled) That's right, Brodlik, keep turning that key.
Who are you?
Never mind who we are, just open the door. We're just your chums come to visit. Now move.
Door unlocked, opened and closed.
Pretty shabby little place. Just what we'd expect from a government employee.
If you're going to rob me, get on with it. You won't get any trouble from
Velcro sound.
Oh! You're
(normal) Never mind what we are. We just want to ask you a few questions, that's all, then we'll be gone and you can forget all about us. I'd really strongly advise that, by the way. The forgetting
part.
Isn't your friend going to take off his pollution mask as well?
(slightly muffled) Why don't you wear one, Mister Brodlik?
Mister? What's the point? I'm third generation full- blown. My father was born fully mutated.
He doesn't like us much.
I'm not sure I blame him.
You people make me sick.
The Doctor removes his pollution mask.
Sorry to hear that.
You're both Koteem agents, aren't you.
No. Mister Brodlik, I'm not going to waste your time or mine. We know that a friend of mine was taken into your er
Security block.
Security block, yes. Her name is Nyssa.
Brodlik gasps.
I see you know who I'm talking about.
What's the point of all this?
The point is, Mister Brodlik, that Nyssa is not guilty of anything, and I need to get her out of there.
You're the Dokter, aren't you?
Yes. Yes, I am.
She's spoken about you.
Is she all right?
Er, yes.
They'll have beaten her up.
Is that right? Is that what you've done to her?
I haven't touched her.
Maybe not you, but the others
I see.
What do you want from me?
We want you to think about your family. And if you don't care about them, think about yourself.
Please, Quain, do you have to do this?
What do you know about my family?
Quain, this isn't necessary.
You want Nyssa back, don't you?
Yes, you know I do.
Then leave
But I don't

Leave this to me, Doctor. There's only one way to deal with these people. Isn't that right, Brodlik? You know about all sorts of nasty little things that happen in the Security block. Maybe you don't do them yourself, but you know, don't you?
I think you can take that as a yes.
So I want you to think about your poor old mum and dad in the nursing home, and yout little sister who stacks barrels at the refinery.
You bast
Yes, we've done our research. Now, just imagine some of the things that happen in your Security block happening to them. You getting the picture?
Yes. Yes.
Right, Doctor. Over to you.
Thank you, Quain.
So what did happen when you went home?
All right, I admit it, I was troubled.
So you sat down with a nice cup of telse and mulled over the predicament of your poor, beautiful little Koteem.
What exactly are you getting at?

And then you came back here later that evening. Yes, I know thought we didn't know about that. You even tail-gated your way in behind a officer so that you wouldn't have to use your security code key. Let me show you a tape. Now there you are, entering the Medical Department. Oh, you didn't know there was a hidden camera there. What a shame. You studied medicine, didn't you, before you specialised in psychiatry.
Yes.
And you knew enough to compare the prisoner Nyssa's blood test results with all the other Koteem blood test results. Well?
They didn't match.
So what did you think that meant? Well?
I don't know. I honestly don't know. But if the blood didn't match then she couldn't have been Koteem, could she.
You're thinking outside your jurisdiction, Brodlik.
Aren't you even curious?
Because her blood type doesn't match with other Koteem samples? That just means she's a Koteem with a different sort of blood.
But it was a totally different blood.
Did you bring this matter up with the duty Medical Officer the next day?
I was intending to, but
You were distracted. A little incident the following day. Let's forget about your presentation, shall we? I'd like to skip to the recording of the next day, Brodlik. Shall we watch?
Fast forwarding.
Have you processed my papers?
What are you?
Why do you want to know? What's the matter? You look scared.
Er, I have processed your papers.
Crackling.
I'm afraid the tape cuts out there. Apparently there was
some fault in the system. I've spoken to the surveillance people about it. They say it was localised power
Convenient though, wasn't it, eh, Brodlik?
Convenient?
For the intruders, I mean.
Er

Because that's just about when it happened, wasn't it? What was the last time line on the tape? About oh seven sixty one? They'd left the building by oh seven sixty eight, so your interview room surveillance camera cut out just a few moments before they entered.
But at the time, I didn't know anything was wrong.
Oh yes, that's right. They had security passes. Good enough to get them past a particularly comatose front desk man who's since been reassigned, and you. Remind me what the intruders told you.
I think you know, sir. Perhaps you'd just like to make your point.
Gilbrook clears his throat and opens a file.
They said they were from the Outer State Affiliates. They had travel documentation and outranked me. They were most insistent I had no choice. Those are your words.
I'm aware of that.
I'm not going to get angry. How's that. So you needn't get all jumpy and worried, because I'm just going to ask you a simple question. What really happened?
What I said. What you've got written down there.
That's what really happened?
That's what really happened.
Travel documentation and all that?
Yes, all that.
Which Outer State Affiliate were they from?
Oh, er, I don't seem to recall which.
Why not tell me about it in more detail.
I don't really remember. It all happened so quickly.
What's that?
Don't you know?
Why would I?
It interferes with the surveillance camera in this room. No one can see or hear us. Your friends gave it to me.
Friends?
The Doctor and some other
The Doctor! Where is he?
Oh, you're almost like a Veln, aren't you? You seem to have feelings, just like us.
You've met the Doctor?
Yes, yes, I've been intimidated. I'm scared. It seems they're going to get away with it and I'll be lucky if I'm not under arrest by the end of the day. But I have a family, and I'm scared for
them, and if I admit it, scared for myself. You have violent friends, don't you, Nyssa of Traken.
I really don't understand what you're talking about.
I'm not very proud of myself. I wish I could be stronger, but I'm frightened. It's as simple as that. So you're going to get what you want. You're going to get away with what you did.
I didn't do anything.
And if you do have even a tiny sliver of compassion in that alien heart of yours, just do me one favour.
What favour?
Just tell me one thing.
If I can.
Why did you do it?
I didn't do anything.

I didn't do anything. It wasn't me. I'm not responsible for my actions. Don't you think I've heard it all before? Maniac and psychopaths gibbering in front of me, blaming it all on their mothers, begging for mercy. They didn't know what they were doing. They don't remember. I've heard every pathetic, miserable, despicable excuse there ever was, Nyssa of Traken! You may not be Koteem, I don't know what you are, but you're clearly working with them, so isn't it enough that you destroyed our world, condemned us all to a slow painful death? Why did you have to come here to mutilate and murder one of us?
Sirens, a struggle, screams
No, stop it! Let go of me! Let go of my arm! Argh! Please, no!
Beautiful.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
GILBROOK: Beautiful.
FORLEON: (aristocratic lady) I'd invested all my family's money into research into a cure. The funds were just pouring away. Every line of research was a blind alley. We started experimenting with the benefits of zero gravity for treatment. We took patients up into an orbital satellite I'd bought off a government. Oh, they were always keen to take my money. Ridiculed me in public, but took my money behind closed doors.
DOCTOR: And the Koteem contacted you.
FORLEON: They did.
NYSSA: Stop it! Let go of me! Ah! Please!
NYSSA: (Inside a large moving diesel-powered ground vehicle. The Doctor groans.)
DOCTOR: Nyssa. Nyssa?
NYSSA: It's all right. I was just getting you a hot drink.
DOCTOR: Oh, thanks. Mmm. You let me sleep.
NYSSA: You needed to.
DOCTOR: Hmm, perhaps. How long was I?
NYSSA: Not that long. Quain says we still have four days to go.
DOCTOR: Oh. How are you feeling?
NYSSA: Well, I've felt better.
DOCTOR: Me too. What's the matter?
NYSSA: Do you think we're doing the right thing?
DOCTOR: The right thing?
NYSSA: Going along with Quain and his people.
DOCTOR: Now there's a question. What exactly is the right thing?
NYSSA: I'm assuming that's one of your rhetorical questions.
DOCTOR: That's often the trouble, isn't it?
NYSSA: What is?
DOCTOR: That question. There's never really one answer. Mmm. Got any more of that?
NYSSA: Yes, here.
NYSSA: It's good, isn't it.
DOCTOR: Mmm.
NYSSA: Just about the only remotely pleasant thing we've encountered on this planet.
DOCTOR: Possibly.
NYSSA: Possibly? Definitely, I'd say
DOCTOR: Yes, I might agree with you, but that would just be our point of view.
NYSSA: You're being very philosophical.
DOCTOR: Am I? Hmm, yes, well, it's all a matter of perspective, isn't it.
NYSSA: Is it? I'm not sure I follow you.
DOCTOR: Well, when you think about it, there are a lot of different perspectives on this planet, aren't there? Points of view. Deeply held convictions. What the security people think, what Quain and his people think, whatever it is the Koteem think.
NYSSA: Are you saying we should never have got involved?
DOCTOR: It's certainly a point of view.
NYSSA: Doctor, we didn't have a choice.
DOCTOR: Maybe we didn't.
BOTH: Maybe we did?
DOCTOR: I did.
NYSSA: You're in a very peculiar mood, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Maybe it's just a question of survival.
NYSSA: Do you mean for the Veln, or the Koteem?
DOCTOR: Or us.
NYSSA: Do you think we're still in danger?
DOCTOR: I think the sooner we get to the Tardis and leave, the better.
GILBROOK: Come.
GILBROOK: Have you got the tapes?
BRODLIK: Er, yes, sir.
GILBROOK: Well, let's not arse about.
GILBROOK: I want to get to the bottom of this.
BRODLIK: Of course.
GILBROOK: Sit. Stick the tape in. I take it you're going to talk me through this? I don't want to sit through hours of the stuff. Just give me the highlights and the headlines.
BRODLIK: I have prepared a report.
GILBROOK: Report? (laughs) Always so present and correct, aren't you, Brodlik.
BRODLIK: I pride myself
GILBROOK: On all the fancy letters after your name, yeah, I know. Didn't help you this time, though, did they? If it weren't for the fact that I've got the Security Minister breathing down my neck about all this, I might take time to enjoy making you squirm. But since I'm Head of Security, and you're supposedly one of my most respected underlings, my arse is very much roasting over the fire as we speak, so get on with it!
BRODLIK: May I?
GILBROOK: Oh, I'll be taping this on my machine.
BRODLIK: I see.
GILBROOK: Any objection? Wouldn't want to miss any of your words of wisdom, would we? Make sure you speak up for the sake of the microphone. Name and rank. That'd be a nice place to start, don't you think?
BRODLIK: Security Department Senior Psychiatric Interrogator Leslar Brodlik reporting to Chief of Security Rolf Gilbrook. Subject, alien incursion.
GILBROOK: By the Koteem.
BRODLIK: Er, that isn't certain.
GILBROOK: What do you mean?
BRODLIK: If you'll permit me to continue, sir.
GILBROOK: You'd better start making sense soon, Brodlik.
BRODLIK: Well, you'll be the judge of that, I'm sure, Chief.
GILBROOK: Very much so.
BRODLIK: This is my first interview with the prisoner, and
GILBROOK: Pause. She is a beauty, isn't she?
BRODLIK: Apart from the bruising to the right eye. Overzealous restraint in the custody processing.
GILBROOK: Oh, my custody boys love their job.
BRODLIK: Yes. I believe you did mention that when you handed me this case.
GILBROOK: Yes. Never mind that. Just get on with it.
BRODLIK: [OC]: Your custody record gives your name as Nyssa Traken. Is that correct? Do you understand me?
NYSSA: [OC]: Yes. Yes, I understand.
NYSSA: May I have something to drink? My mouth's very dry.
BRODLIK: The hospital discharged you after only three days. They said you were recovered. Are you feeling ill?
NYSSA: Only if you count being beaten up by your thugs as illness.
BRODLIK: You resisted arrest, I believe.
NYSSA: I didn't get a chance. And I didn't say my name was Nyssa Traken. I said it was Nyssa of Traken. Now can I have something to drink, please?
BRODLIK: Yes, there's telse in the flask. Help yourself.
NYSSA: Er, oh, thank you.
BRODLIK: Smoke?
NYSSA: What?
NYSSA: Er, no. If you don't mind, I don't do that.
BRODLIK: Strange. I think I will.
NYSSA: Why is it strange?
BRODLIK: (exhales slowly) I believe I'm the one who asks questions. You understand the seriousness of the charge?
NYSSA: I understand that your thugs jumped to conclusions and didn't give me a chance to speak.
BRODLIK: Some might say that was understandable given the circumstances.
NYSSA: Understandable?
BRODLIK: You've been sent to me because you made certain assertions at the time of your custody processing. I'm the Senior Psychiatric Interrogator. I want to know why you said those things.
NYSSA: Psychiatric? You think I'm mad.
BRODLIK: Er, you mentioned that you weren't from this planet, that you were just here on a short stop while the Dokter waited for the Tardis to er. and then the officer said you became very garbled.
NYSSA: I was suffering from a concussion. Your officers knocked me out. I'd only just regained consciousness when they started asking me questions.
BRODLIK: The arresting officers report that you became violent at the scene of the crime.
NYSSA: As I recall, there were at least four arresting officers, all of them considerably bigger and stronger than me. The only violence came from them.
BRODLIK: Do you wish to make an official complaint against these officers?
NYSSA: I wish to be released so that
BRODLIK: So that you could return to the er, the Tardis. Who is this Dokter you mention?
NYSSA: He's a friend of mine.
BRODLIK: [OC]: Oh? And where is he now?
NYSSA: [OC]: I don't know.
GILBROOK: Pause it there.
BRODLIK: Is there something?
GILBROOK: This Doctor bloke. We got him on security cameras, didn't we?
BRODLIK: Er, I believe so.
GILBROOK: Wait a minute. They printed off a still for me. Ah, yes. This him?
BRODLIK: Er, yes. Yes, I believe so.
GILBROOK: If you'd got her to describe him in the first place, we could have had him picked up and you'd have saved us a lot of hassle.
BRODLIK: My job was to determine Nyssa's mental condition and
GILBROOK: Oh, on first name terms.
BRODLIK: It's simply the prisoner's name. It's important to use their names to gain their trust.
GILBROOK: Oh, yes, very diligent, Brodlik. All right, get on with it.
BRODLIK: Perhaps I should move on to the next tape I've selected.
GILBROOK: Did you have the medical report on her by the time
GILBROOK: you did the first interview?
BRODLIK: No. I was interrupted by the duty Medical Officer. I went to his office and looked over his reports, then returned to talk further with er, the prisoner.
GILBROOK: Ah, I see. And what happened when you resumed the interview?
BRODLIK: Er, well, the next day I was
GILBROOK: No, no, not the next day. Play me the rest of the first day's tape. Just wind it on until after you got the medical report.
BRODLIK: There isn't much of interest.
GILBROOK: Play it!
BRODLIK: [OC]: I'm sorry we were interrupted.
NYSSA: [OC]: When are you going to let me go?
BRODLIK: I have your medical report here.
NYSSA: Oh yes, they took a blood sample from me. Rather brutally, as I remember.
BRODLIK: Hmm. And the tests on your blood confirm that you are alien to Veln. You look surprised.
NYSSA: I thought
BRODLIK: I would have presumed that you were aware you were not a native of this world.
NYSSA: Yes. It's just that
BRODLIK: Yes?
NYSSA: I didn't know that people on this planet were aware of aliens.
BRODLIK: Everyone knows of Koteem.
NYSSA: Koteem?
BRODLIK: Your legacy is clear for all to see.
NYSSA: My legacy?
BRODLIK: You claim not to know what your people did to this planet?
NYSSA: Let's assume I don't know what my people did.
BRODLIK: Assume? I'm afraid I don't have time to play games. You're serious, aren't you.
NYSSA: So now you think I'm mad. But tell me anyway, Brodlik.
BRODLIK: Tell you?
NYSSA: The legacy of the Koteem.
BRODLIK: You're looking at it now. Oh, this is ridiculous.
NYSSA: What is? And what am I supposed to be looking at?
BRODLIK: Me. You're looking at me, aren't you? And it's ridiculous that you'd think I believed you didn't know about the Koteem.
NYSSA: But you do believe me, don't you. You're a psychiatrist, a police psychiatrist. I think you Know when people are being less than honest.
BRODLIK: All right, I'll play along. What do you see when you look at my face?
NYSSA: Er, I'm not sure what
BRODLIK: Yes, I'm good at Knowing when people are being less than honest, and that's what you are being now. I'll make it easy for
BRODLIK: you. You see ugliness when you look at my face. When you look at the face of most people in the world. Distorted skin tissue, abnormal bone structure. Not like your face. Not beautiful like you.
NYSSA: I
BRODLIK: There are only a few of us, the impossibly rich, the elite few who indulge in cosmetic adjustments to make them look like, well, how the Veln looked once.
NYSSA: Once?
BRODLIK: But you'd know all about that, wouldn't you.
NYSSA: Would I?
BRODLIK: You were arrested on Forleon's estate, weren't you.
NYSSA: I, I don't know. Was I? I remember trees and grass. Flowers.
BRODLIK: That'll be Forleon's estate, all right. There's nowhere else in this country like that.
NYSSA: No flowers?
BRODLIK: Oh yes, of course, I forgot. You don't know anything. Didn't you look at the sky?
NYSSA: Sky?
BRODLIK: (laughs) Oh, you're very good.
NYSSA: Good? I
BRODLIK: But this is impossible. Of course you know what the Koteem did. The pollution in the sky. The clouds that we've had to stare at for four generations, dark blue at sunset and bright emerald in the midday summer sun.
NYSSA: Dyestrial pollution? And this race, the Koteem, they polluted your atmosphere? They caused
BRODLIK: The genetic disfigurement. Yes, that's your people did.
NYSSA: But if they did this to you, why do they still come to your planet? Presumably they do, since you don't seem that surprised to find an alien here.
BRODLIK: We know that you send agents to our world. Our security people have had to deal with a number of them.
NYSSA: Deal? And now that you're sure I'm a Koteem, you'll be handing me over to your security people. Or is there something stopping you?
BRODLIK: There's nothing stopping me. I shall process your papers and hand you over.
NYSSA: Brodlik, I'm not a Koteem.
BRODLIK: That's impossible. Your blood
NYSSA: My blood test showed I was not a native of this planet. Am I right?
BRODLIK: Of course.
NYSSA: So it's tested against Veln blood.
BRODLIK: Yes.
NYSSA: Was it tested against other Koteem samples?
BRODLIK: I've no idea.
NYSSA: But you're thinking about it.
GILBROOK: You should have handed her over to Security. Why didn't you?
BRODLIK: By the time I'd
GILBROOK: No, not later. At that point. The moment you were sure she was Koteem. You should have
BRODLIK: I wasn't sure she
GILBROOK: Oh. Now we get to it.
BRODLIK: Get to what?
GILBROOK: So what did you do?
BRODLIK: I, I don't follow you. I
GILBROOK: Shall I tell you what you did, Brodlik? You took matters into your own hands.
BRODLIK: I had doubts. I wanted to, to check,
GILBROOK: Check up on the blood test results? To quiz the Security Department's duty Medical Officer if you could? Yes, I know. That's bad enough in itself, but at this point, at the point when you left her in her comfortable little interview cell, what precisely did you do?
BRODLIK: I'm not sure what you're trying to
GILBROOK: Oh, Brodlik, Brodlik, Brodlik. I'm through playing games with you. Wake up! Haven't you got the message yet? This isn't an interview. You're not giving a report. You're in trouble. You went home, Brodlik. You went home early. I saw your face on the tape. You were a puzzled little Brodlik, weren't you? Oh, you psychiatric types. Always thought you were on the verge of being just as crazy as the nutters you deal with. Not very stable, are you? The pretty little alien girl rattled your cage, didn't she? And you went home early, all hot and bothered, to think about it, to plan what to do next for your cosy little case study. Never mind that you were breaking every major security regulation we have.
BRODLIK: I had completed my allotted hours for that
GILBROOK: And now you're lying! Dear me. You went home three hours early, back to your miserable little apartment.
QUAIN: (slightly muffled) That's right, Brodlik, keep turning that key.
BRODLIK: Who are you?
QUAIN: Never mind who we are, just open the door. We're just your chums come to visit. Now move.
QUAIN: Pretty shabby little place. Just what we'd expect from a government employee.
BRODLIK: If you're going to rob me, get on with it. You won't get any trouble from
BRODLIK: Oh! You're
QUAIN: (normal) Never mind what we are. We just want to ask you a few questions, that's all, then we'll be gone and you can forget all about us. I'd really strongly advise that, by the way. The forgetting
QUAIN: part.
BRODLIK: Isn't your friend going to take off his pollution mask as well?
DOCTOR: (slightly muffled) Why don't you wear one, Mister Brodlik?
BRODLIK: Mister? What's the point? I'm third generation full- blown. My father was born fully mutated.
QUAIN: He doesn't like us much.
DOCTOR: I'm not sure I blame him.
BRODLIK: You people make me sick.
DOCTOR: Sorry to hear that.
BRODLIK: You're both Koteem agents, aren't you.
DOCTOR: No. Mister Brodlik, I'm not going to waste your time or mine. We know that a friend of mine was taken into your er
QUAIN: Security block.
DOCTOR: Security block, yes. Her name is Nyssa.
DOCTOR: I see you know who I'm talking about.
BRODLIK: What's the point of all this?
DOCTOR: The point is, Mister Brodlik, that Nyssa is not guilty of anything, and I need to get her out of there.
BRODLIK: You're the Dokter, aren't you?
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, I am.
BRODLIK: She's spoken about you.
DOCTOR: Is she all right?
BRODLIK: Er, yes.
QUAIN: They'll have beaten her up.
DOCTOR: Is that right? Is that what you've done to her?
BRODLIK: I haven't touched her.
QUAIN: Maybe not you, but the others
DOCTOR: I see.
BRODLIK: What do you want from me?
QUAIN: We want you to think about your family. And if you don't care about them, think about yourself.
DOCTOR: Please, Quain, do you have to do this?
BRODLIK: What do you know about my family?
DOCTOR: Quain, this isn't necessary.
QUAIN: You want Nyssa back, don't you?
DOCTOR: Yes, you know I do.
QUAIN: Then leave
DOCTOR: But I don't
QUAIN: Leave this to me, Doctor. There's only one way to deal with these people. Isn't that right, Brodlik? You know about all sorts of nasty little things that happen in the Security block. Maybe you don't do them yourself, but you know, don't you?
DOCTOR: I think you can take that as a yes.
QUAIN: So I want you to think about your poor old mum and dad in the nursing home, and yout little sister who stacks barrels at the refinery.
BRODLIK: You bast
QUAIN: Yes, we've done our research. Now, just imagine some of the things that happen in your Security block happening to them. You getting the picture?
BRODLIK: Yes. Yes.
QUAIN: Right, Doctor. Over to you.
DOCTOR: Thank you, Quain.
GILBROOK: So what did happen when you went home?
BRODLIK: All right, I admit it, I was troubled.
GILBROOK: So you sat down with a nice cup of telse and mulled over the predicament of your poor, beautiful little Koteem.
BRODLIK: What exactly are you getting at?
GILBROOK: And then you came back here later that evening. Yes, I know thought we didn't know about that. You even tail-gated your way in behind a officer so that you wouldn't have to use your security code key. Let me show you a tape. Now there you are, entering the Medical Department. Oh, you didn't know there was a hidden camera there. What a shame. You studied medicine, didn't you, before you specialised in psychiatry.
BRODLIK: Yes.
GILBROOK: And you knew enough to compare the prisoner Nyssa's blood test results with all the other Koteem blood test results. Well?
BRODLIK: They didn't match.
GILBROOK: So what did you think that meant? Well?
BRODLIK: I don't know. I honestly don't know. But if the blood didn't match then she couldn't have been Koteem, could she.
GILBROOK: You're thinking outside your jurisdiction, Brodlik.
BRODLIK: Aren't you even curious?
GILBROOK: Because her blood type doesn't match with other Koteem samples? That just means she's a Koteem with a different sort of blood.
BRODLIK: But it was a totally different blood.
GILBROOK: Did you bring this matter up with the duty Medical Officer the next day?
BRODLIK: I was intending to, but
GILBROOK: You were distracted. A little incident the following day. Let's forget about your presentation, shall we? I'd like to skip to the recording of the next day, Brodlik. Shall we watch?
NYSSA: Have you processed my papers?
BRODLIK: What are you?
NYSSA: Why do you want to know? What's the matter? You look scared.
BRODLIK: Er, I have processed your papers.
BRODLIK: I'm afraid the tape cuts out there. Apparently there was
BRODLIK: some fault in the system. I've spoken to the surveillance people about it. They say it was localised power
GILBROOK: Convenient though, wasn't it, eh, Brodlik?
BRODLIK: Convenient?
GILBROOK: For the intruders, I mean.
BRODLIK: Er
GILBROOK: Because that's just about when it happened, wasn't it? What was the last time line on the tape? About oh seven sixty one? They'd left the building by oh seven sixty eight, so your interview room surveillance camera cut out just a few moments before they entered.
BRODLIK: But at the time, I didn't know anything was wrong.
GILBROOK: Oh yes, that's right. They had security passes. Good enough to get them past a particularly comatose front desk man who's since been reassigned, and you. Remind me what the intruders told you.
BRODLIK: I think you know, sir. Perhaps you'd just like to make your point.
GILBROOK: They said they were from the Outer State Affiliates. They had travel documentation and outranked me. They were most insistent I had no choice. Those are your words.
BRODLIK: I'm aware of that.
GILBROOK: I'm not going to get angry. How's that. So you needn't get all jumpy and worried, because I'm just going to ask you a simple question. What really happened?
BRODLIK: What I said. What you've got written down there.
GILBROOK: That's what really happened?
BRODLIK: That's what really happened.
GILBROOK: Travel documentation and all that?
BRODLIK: Yes, all that.
GILBROOK: Which Outer State Affiliate were they from?
BRODLIK: Oh, er, I don't seem to recall which.
GILBROOK: Why not tell me about it in more detail.
BRODLIK: I don't really remember. It all happened so quickly.
NYSSA: What's that?
BRODLIK: Don't you know?
NYSSA: Why would I?
BRODLIK: It interferes with the surveillance camera in this room. No one can see or hear us. Your friends gave it to me.
NYSSA: Friends?
BRODLIK: The Doctor and some other
NYSSA: The Doctor! Where is he?
BRODLIK: Oh, you're almost like a Veln, aren't you? You seem to have feelings, just like us.
NYSSA: You've met the Doctor?
BRODLIK: Yes, yes, I've been intimidated. I'm scared. It seems they're going to get away with it and I'll be lucky if I'm not under arrest by the end of the day. But I have a family, and I'm scared for
BRODLIK: them, and if I admit it, scared for myself. You have violent friends, don't you, Nyssa of Traken.
NYSSA: I really don't understand what you're talking about.
BRODLIK: I'm not very proud of myself. I wish I could be stronger, but I'm frightened. It's as simple as that. So you're going to get what you want. You're going to get away with what you did.
NYSSA: I didn't do anything.
BRODLIK: And if you do have even a tiny sliver of compassion in that alien heart of yours, just do me one favour.
NYSSA: What favour?
BRODLIK: Just tell me one thing.
NYSSA: If I can.
BRODLIK: Why did you do it?
NYSSA: I didn't do anything.
BRODLIK: I didn't do anything. It wasn't me. I'm not responsible for my actions. Don't you think I've heard it all before? Maniac and psychopaths gibbering in front of me, blaming it all on their mothers, begging for mercy. They didn't know what they were doing. They don't remember. I've heard every pathetic, miserable, despicable excuse there ever was, Nyssa of Traken! You may not be Koteem, I don't know what you are, but you're clearly working with them, so isn't it enough that you destroyed our world, condemned us all to a slow painful death? Why did you have to come here to mutilate and murder one of us?
NYSSA: No, stop it! Let go of me! Let go of my arm! Argh! Please, no!
GILBROOK: Beautiful.

elements.text: [Part Two]
Birds call. Moving through foliage.
Nyssa.
Rifles cocked.
All right, stay where you are.
Please, you have to get out of my way. My friend is
Our people are dealing with that. Don't go getting yourself all worked up. Just stand still.
The only way you're going to stop me is to use that.
Oh, we'll use it all right, don't you worry.
Ah. Yes. I believe you would, wouldn't you.
The Lady Forleon's instructions are very clear on matters of security and secrecy.
Secrecy?
And we can't have you running around out here, can we? Someone might see you.
And presumably they might hear my friend crying out as well.
Distant scream.
Look! Can't you hear she's in trouble? You've got to let me. Just
Struggle.
She's a friend of yours, is she? Well, one way or another, it's over.
How long since you landed?
Er, not long.
Where's your pod?
Pod? Well, somewhere over behind those trees, but
Which trees?
Er, further up the hillside. I can't quite. Look, look, this isn't important. I have to
This is Seedleson, patrol seven, calling Control. Hear me?
[OC]: Hear you.
Koteem pod in zone four.
Koteem?
Check it out and retrieve. Murone and me have the occupant. Bringing him in.
[OC]: Understood.
Er, I think my pod is probably perfectly all right where it is.
Sirens approaching.
Right, that's our cue to get moving. Come on. Er, what do we call you?
Don't be shy.
Doctor.
Dok Ter?
Doctor, yes.
Right, Doctor, you'd better come with us, or you're going to end up right in the dung, mate.

I know. I can hear them. One of the locals must have called the Security block. Yeah. Mmm. Well, the poor wretch must have been pretty determined to get out of the grounds. Why the hell didn't you stop (pause) Wait a minute. Have they gone? Did you see what happened? Another girl? Who was she? I see. Well, find out what you can. Thank you.
Phone put down, then something thrown onto the floor to break.
Oh! As if this wasn't difficult enough.
Knock on door.
Come!
Door opens.
Lady Forleon, we
Send a maid in to have that cleared up. Yes, I'm angry. Are you surprised? What do you want?
We think the replacement's arrived.
That's not possible. We haven't even sent a report to them.
I know, but he's here. We're sending a team after his pod.
He came down in broad daylight? They're taking risks. Why didn't we spot it on entry?
It's happened before.
Not for a long time.
Well, now it's happened again.
You never miss the obvious, Quain.
Just as well, around here.
Well, I'd better meet him. What's his name?
Dokter.
Unusual choice of cover name. I really must speak to him about that. What's the matter?
He seems a bit confused.
Must have had a bumpy landing. Probably came in too fast. We'll have to give him time to recover before we operate.
Right. Well, er, I'll go and get him.
If you would.
Telephone rings.
Forleon. So they arrested her? And our girl was definitely dead? I see. Was she? That doesn't make sense. Did you get a shot of her? Good. Get me a copy as quickly as you can. Thank you.
Phone down. Knock on door.
Yes? Come.
Door opens.
Dokter?
Yes. I take it you're Lady Forleon.
Of course. Did you suffer any injury?
Er, no. Why would you think I had?
Please, there was no criticism implied. We are, of course, grateful. It's just that the timing of your landing was, shall we say, somewhat unorthodox.
Hmm. Well, this is all very fascinating, Lady Forleon. Tell me, am I a prisoner here?
Prisoner? Of course not.
Even though I was brought here at gunpoint. Then I'm free to leave?
Leave? Why would you want to leave?
So I'm not free to leave. I see.
What do you see? Please, sit down.
I'd prefer not. You see, I'm rather afraid that my friend's in trouble
Friend? There were two of you in the pod? I didn't know that was possible.

Well, be that as it may, I left her by the pod while I headed for your rather impressive looking house. When I was halfway here, I heard her scream. I think it was her. Well, at least I'm very much afraid it was her.
You knew the girl?
Yes, of course. She's my friend.
Dokter, I'd like Quain to check you over. Would you have any objection to that?
Do I get a choice?
Well, I am asking you.
And why would I need checking over, exactly?
To be blunt, you're not making much sense.
Am I not?
No, you're not. For example, I don't see how you could have known the girl, if you've only just arrived. You did arrive on Veln today.
Yes, we did. And perhaps it's time for me to be blunt. Do you know anything about dyestrial pollution?
I don't see the relevance.
You do know that's the reason your sky is green?
Of course I know that. It's the reason for a lot of things on Veln. It's the reason you're here, isn't it?

It's precisely the reason I'm here. While my (pause) er pod was recovering, I thought I might take it upon myself to warn someone here about the dangerous side-effects of raw dyestrial fallout. Perhaps I shouldn't interfere, but I thought it wouldn't do any harm. Exactly the opposite, I'd hoped, but quite frankly now I'm regretting it because I left my friend
Forleon laughs.
I'm sorry, have I said something funny?
No, no. Now, lets see.
What are you looking at?
I'm looking for a bump on your head, Dokter. No, nothing. No obvious injury. But I'm afraid I'm going to have to insist that you see Quain before the operation.
Operation? And what if I refuse?
Er, I really think it'd be in your best interests.
Do you?
All right, all right. I'll mention it in my next report to your people. See what they say.
My people?
Yes. Well, we have to tell them about the girl anyway.
Would it surprise you to know that I haven't got the faintest idea what you're talking about?
(laughs) Frankly, no.
Look, please, I just need to see if Nyssa
Knock on door.
Come!
Door opens.
Lady Forleon, you have got to see this.
What is it, Quain?
We found his er, pod.
Er, perhaps
We've brought it to the outhouse as usual, to be ready for transportation, but er, I really do think you have to see it with your own eyes.
Dokter? Please, come with us.
Yes. Yes, of course. Why not.
Murone?
What is it?
That picture from the main gate is coming through. They say we have to get it to the Lady right away.
When doesn't she want something right away?
Money talks, my friend. Money talks. She's had her own way all her life.
Huh. All right for some, isn't it.
Don't know it, Murone. If she's true to her word, it'll be all right for all of us some day too.
Yeah. Yeah. Let's hope so.
Let's have a look.
Who is it?
Main gate say this is the girl Security nabbed.
She's a beauty, isn't she?
Koteem?
Either that or one of the rich bitches.
Poor pudding.
Why'd you say that?
They'll have her for murder, won't they? And there's not a thing we can do about it.
Door closes. Footsteps.
This (laughs) This is?
(laughing) I Know. Apparently. Well, they did find it where he said his pod had landed.
This is your pod, Dokter?
Well, I admit that it probably isn't exactly an orthodox design.
Knocking.
It's made of wood.
(laughs) I know.
This isn't a landing pod. It's, well, it looks more like a poacher's shack. But the colour, and these strange markings? I've seen Koteem script before, but never like this.
It's disguised.
The markings?
No, the whole thing. Sort of camouflage.
Camouflage? Shouldn't it fit in with its surroundings if it's camouflage? I've never seen anything like this before.
Well, it's anew model. We call it a Tardis.
Tardis?
Yes, anyway, if you'll just bear with me, I think we're getting a little off the point here. I need to find
The point? What does he mean?
Dokter seems, as you warned me, a little confused. Quain, I'd like to

I assure you, I'm not confused. I don't need checking over. It's this situation that's getting increasingly confusing, and the reason it's getting confusing is that I'm not who you think I am. I'm from another planet.
Your point being?
He is confused.
Ah, yes, of course. The pods. You were expecting someone from another planet.
Of course.
But. Forgive me, but I was under the impression that Veln technology hadn't developed to the level of interplanetary exploration.
That's right, but in this
No, wait a minute. Please wait. I'm sorry to cut you off, and I'll be perfectly willing to discuss this as much as you want later, but I have to find out if my friend is safe.
Ah, the girl. He says he knows
Which girl?
Well, her name's Nyssa, but
Nyssa!
Yes, but that's not the
I'd assumed you were talking about Veline.
You've heard that she's dead?
Yes. And there'll be questions to answer about that.
Wait a minute. Veline? Who's Veline?
Who's Nyssa?
Door opens.
Er, excuse me, Lady Forleon.
Door closes.
What is it, Murone?
Main gate said you wanted to see this as soon as it came through.
Ah, yes.
Is she a beauty?
She is. She really is.
May I see? Nyssa!
That's your friend?
Yes.
And she arrived with you?
Yes, but what's happening in this picture? When was it taken?
Shortly after Seedleson and Murone found you. I'm afraid your friend has been arrested.
Arrested? There's blood on her hands and these look like
Uniformed Veln security. Not known for their subtlety, especially when it comes to beauties.
Beauties? Why are they arresting her?
For murder, we think.
Murder? Who's she supposed to have murdered?
Veline. What do you think they'll make of the body?
They won't be able to work it out. They might as well be using blunt axes for all the good their government issue autopsy equipment will be.
Poor Veline.
Look, I realise that perhaps I should have asked this earlier, but believe it or not I was trying to avoid confusion. What exactly is going on here? Well?
Murone?
Lady Forleon.
Weapon cocked.
Now, there's no need for that.
The fact that you don't know what exactly is going on here is making me very nervous, Dokter.
Noisy diesel ground vehicle stops. Wind blowing.
We've stopped.
Yes.
Do you think we've arrived?
Possibly. Or Quain may have just wanted a rest. He's been driving for hours, after all.
Do you trust him? I know that seems an ungrateful question to ask, since he helped me to escape.
I couldn't have done it without him.
So you do trust him.
He's helping us, that's all I can be sure of.
You mean you don't think he's doing it out of altruism.
Well, there is an argument that no one is ever truly selfless in their actions, that there's always a pragmatic motive somewhere.
He's probably just doing what the Koteem want, isn't he?
Just obeying orders, is he? Well, I think the only thing that should concern us is that he's taking us to the Tardis. That's our pragmatic motive. How does that sound to you, Nyssa?
Very pragmatic.
Yes. And considering everything we've been through on this planet, I think it's best if we keep it that way.
Door opens. Wind louder.
You two all right?
Yes, thanks.
Manage to get any rest?
A little. You must be exhausted.
Ah, I'm all right.
Are we there yet?
Yes. Come on, out you come.
Walking in strong wind, on snow.
Where's the Tardis?
Not far.
I can't see it. How far, exactly?
Follow me. This way.
It's like being back in Alaska.
Hopefully not as dangerous. Well, Quain, what now?
This is it.
What is? It's just, well, a hill covered in snow.
I thought you'd understand the principle of camouflage. Doctor?
I don't follow you.
Didn't you say your pod, your Tardis, was camouflaged?
Yes. Are you saying this hill is some kind of camouflaged building? A base of some sort?
Of some sort. Wait a moment.
Beeping.
What's that? Koteem technology?
Precisely. You don't trust me, us, do you?
To be honest, Quain, I don't know.
What we're doing on Veln is for the good of everyone.
But not everyone agrees with you.
There's a lot of ignorance about.
Does it matter whether we trust you or not?
We'd prefer it if you did. All right, have it your own way. Here we go.
Sizzle.
It's a forcefield. A forcefield with a holographic projection on it that fits in with the surroundings.
That's right. Veln security can't pick it up.
I suppose that's the advantage of importing advanced alien technology, isn't it? What's happening?
Activating the entry port.
Whoosh.
After you.
Doctor?
Follow me, Nyssa.
Walking, whoosh. Just the wind.
Echoing area.
Forgive me for pointing out the obvious, Quain.
But still no Tardis.
I couldn't have put it better myself, Nyssa.
No, this is a sort of holding area.
And what are you holding us for?
Let me guess. You're not just going to let us get into the Tardis and leave.
Building energy noise.
Er
Quain, what's going on? Doctor, this is getting distinctly uncomfortable.
I know. At a guess, I'd say it was some form of rather unsubtle bioscan.
Be patient, Doctor. They're not going to hurt you.
They?
Are you still non-committal about trusting him, Doctor?
Noise stops. Sighs of relief.
Let's just say I'm struggling to keep an open mind on the subject.
There should be no lasting ill effects.
Should be? That's not very reassuring.
By they, did you mean the Koteem, Quain?
Yes.
Ah. An open door. An invitation.
Or a trap.
The Tardis is beyond that doorway.
I can't see it from here.
Would I be right in guessing that the Koteem are beyond that door too?
(electronic voice) Quain, bring them to me.
I'm guessing we don't have a choice.
Didn't you say there are always choices?
Not if we want to get off this planet.
Doctor? Nyssa? This way please.
Hmm. Spiders, flies and parlours spring to mind.
I'm not sure I understand the allusion.
I'm not sure you'd want to.
You're going to regret this, Gilbrook.

Obtaining a search warrant for the Forleon Estate? Having my grubby little men tramping mud all through your lovely expensive house? Seeing you going a little purple in the face because for once in your sickeningly rich privileged life, you're not getting your own way? Er, just remind me about the bit I'm going to be regretting, Lady Forleon? And now you've resorted to giving me that superior smug look of yours. Yes, I've seen that in the papers often enough. That beautiful smile. That beautifully surgically reconstructed smile. Can you even tell when I'm smiling? Can you even bear to look at my filthy, ugly face?
Gilbrook, you have overreached your authority.

I have to look at filthy, ugly faces like mine all my life. Do you know how that feels? It feels normal. And people like you, people who sit up here in your rich palaces, creaming off profits, bribing and corrupting, but with so many government contacts no One can touch you, you think you're perfect and beautiful. But to me, you know what? To me you are ugly. I feel sick to look at you. Yes. And I know that some high up contact or other of yours will call his boss who will call my boss, and I'll get sat on. But that's going to take time, my dear beautiful lady. And in that time, I'm going to find proof that you've been harbouring alien agents somewhere in all this luxury, and then all your important friends will run for cover, and you and your beautiful buddies will end up behind bars. Do you know what they do to beautiful boo-boos like you in penitentiaries, en? (chuckles) Oh, I'm sure you can guess.
You have no right
Telephone rings.
Gilbrook. Hmm. But no sign of this Dokter and Nyssa? All right, round up the others and start the blood tests.
Telephone down.
Oh, sorry, Lady Forleon. You were saying? Oh dear, gone all sulky, have we? Don't frown, my little beauty. You might spoil that lovely face of yours.
You have no evidence to support your claims.
Oh, why would you think that? Because your people had intimidated the witness into keeping quiet?
This is ridiculous. I

Beautiful faces are so expressive, aren't they? Every little twitch means something. In all my years in security, I flatter myself I can see what every prisoner is thinking. Yeah, I know you find that hard to believe, that I could discern any subtlety through all the scar tissue, those sores, and the bones in their faces all distorted and twisted, but I can. So you, Lady Beautiful, you can't hide anything from me. I know you're lying, and I know you're worried.
Telephone rings.
Yes? Oh, really? I'm greatly encouraged. I'll be there in just a moment. Thanks.
Telephone down.
I can tell you're curious.
I'm not playing games with you, Gilbrook.

Why not? It's all you've got left. My people have found a sealed basement. Took quite a bit of finding. Oh, now you're very worried indeed. You wouldn't happen to have a key, would you? Oh, don't worry. We'll blow it open. Then we'll find out what you lot have really been getting up to. I think you'd better come with me, don't you?
Doctor, Nyssa, it is clear that you are familiar with the sights of creatures alien to yourselves.
If you scanned us, you must know that like you we are aliens on this world. May I ask to whom I am speaking?
I am a Koteem.
We gathered that much.
I prefer not to give you further identification.
Why? Because what you're doing on this planet is illegal?
Some would choose to interpret our actions as such.
And why would that be?

My database cannot find a match for your bioscan results. Lady Forleon has informed me that you originate from the planets Gallifrey and Traken. I have no knowledge of these planets or their policies on Galactic Sector Council resolutions. Please enlighten me.
We have no policy. It's no concern of ours that some
might consider your actions here illegal. In fact, we barely understand the situation here on Veln.
All we know is that it's dangerous for us here, and we'd like to leave as soon as possible, please.
If I could he sure that you were telling the truth, then I would let you go. But how can I be sure?
Well, er, you could just try believing us.
(laughs) You would advocate that I should trust you?
Yes. Is that so strange?
Trust is a commodity in somewhat short supply in this sector of the galaxy.
What a pity.

Your bioscans and the way you speak indicate highly developed intelligence. You must have formed an opinion of our work here, even with the little knowledge you claim to have. I am attempting to trust you. Your hesitation is not reassuring me that I am wise to do so.
Very well.
Doctor.
They say honesty is the best policy, Nyssa.
And who precisely are they?
It's either that or make a run for it, and somehow I don't think that's going to work.
Your craft is held in a forcefield.
You need hardly have said so.
Do you have anything to say?
Let me see. Now I've met you
Yes?
Careful, Doctor.
I think you have something in common with the people of Veln.
And what would that be?
Ooo, at a guess, dyestrial pollution.
Strangled noise.
Sounds like I hit a sore spot.
[OC]: Charges set, sir.
All right, people. Let's stand back. Oh, and you too, my Lady. Wouldn't want you to get a scratch on that beautiful face of yours.
I insist you contact your superiors. The terms of your warrant
Shut up! That's better. All right, somebody press that button.
KaBOOM! Flying debris. Coughing.
Can we get the lights on in there?
Gilbrook, please, listen to me.
Something to say?
You mustn't go in there.
Oh, you're really scared, aren't you.
Look, I can't think of a better way to say this. You won't understand what you see in there.
Oh dear, ugly and stupid, am I?
No, no, I didn't mean that. I
Oh, just ugly, then.
Yes. Yes! You are ugly. Ugly and dying, all of you.
Oh, now we hear it. So that makes you better than us, does it?
Yes. Because we have a chance at life. A chance to rebuild Veln. A chance to stop all the suffering.
Well, you can do a lot with a pretty face in this world, darling, but you can't put right what those bastard Koteem did to us.
Please
Do you really think a bit of cosmetic surgery's gonna mean you live longer, hey?
It isn't cosmetic surgery.
So I gather your people, the Koteem ,suffered a planetary disaster involving some sort of dyestrial energy fusion plant.
There was no disaster, only the decision to use dyestrial as our primary source of energy. By the time our medical scientists detected the genetic damage to our people, it was too late.
But how does that relate to the Veln?
The story of what happened to the Veln is well known in this sector. Do you mean to claim that you have no knowledge of it? I find that hard to believe.
Which makes it pretty pitiful as a lie, wouldn't you say?

All we do know is that the Veln government hold you responsible for the dyestrial pollution in their atmosphere, for the genetic and ecological damage caused here, and that you're trying to make amends.
There was an accident.
Accident?
Our transport ships are forbidden to enter inhabited solar systems.
Transport ships? You mean ships transporting dyestrial waste?

Highly dangerous toxins. Once the Koteem government had decided to phase out dyestrial power plants, the biggest problem was the disposal of these toxins. The Galactic Sector Council gave us permission to dispose of these toxins in uninhabited areas of the galaxy.
And you thought this solar system was uninhabited.
No. Our people knew of the Veln, an undeveloped humanoid race only just beginning to venture beyond its planet.
So you didn't bring your dyestrial waste here, so how
Not officially.
What do you mean?

Avoiding the Veln solar system added a significant extra cost to those employed to dispose of the toxins. Their operations became more profitable if they deliberately ignored the fact that the occasional transport commander showed the initiative to
Take a short cut. I see.

There was an accident in high orbit above Veln. Dyestrial waste was released. The ship was destroyed. The planet was terminally polluted. That was four Veln generations ago. In another four generations, we, the Koteem, will be guilty of genocide.
I see. And now you're planning to prevent that.

Yeah, yeah, well keep her there. Right. Oh, and listen. Any word from the Ministry? Oh, thought as much. Well, senda message that I'll contact them as soon as I'm back at my office. I don't care if they don't like it, that's what I'm saying, all right? Good, because I think we've found ourselves all the evidence we need down here. Yeah. Right little chambers of horrors it is, too. Some of the stuff down here I, I think it's Koteem technology.
Sir.
What have you got for me?
It's like a vid-record, only some kind of see-through ball thing. Our boys think they've worked out how to use it.
Right, let's go.
Beeps.
[OC]: Veline, how are you feeling?
[OC]: All right.
I think I'm all right.
Just take a few deep breaths. You'll be fine. Pulse is a little high, that's all.
Sorry, I'm being stupid, I know.
It's fine, Veline. Don't worry. Ready to start?
Ready to start.
Good girl.
All right, Quain. Begin the procedure.
Squelchy sounds.
Are you ready, Quain?
Everything checks out.
Commence intramission.
Zap. Veline screams.
