So you, Lady Beautiful, you can't hide anything from me. I know you're lying, and I know you're worried.
GILBROOK: Yes? Oh, really? I'm greatly encouraged. I'll be there in just a moment. Thanks.
GILBROOK: I can tell you're curious.
FORLEON: I'm not playing games with you, Gilbrook.
GILBROOK: Why not? It's all you've got left. My people have found a sealed basement. Took quite a bit of finding. Oh, now you're very worried indeed. You wouldn't happen to have a key, would you? Oh, don't worry. We'll blow it open. Then we'll find out what you lot have really been getting up to. I think you'd better come with me, don't you?
KOTEEM: Doctor, Nyssa, it is clear that you are familiar with the sights of creatures alien to yourselves.
DOCTOR: If you scanned us, you must know that like you we are aliens on this world. May I ask to whom I am speaking?
KOTEEM: I am a Koteem.
NYSSA: We gathered that much.
KOTEEM: I prefer not to give you further identification.
DOCTOR: Why? Because what you're doing on this planet is illegal?
KOTEEM: Some would choose to interpret our actions as such.
NYSSA: And why would that be?
KOTEEM: My database cannot find a match for your bioscan results. Lady Forleon has informed me that you originate from the planets Gallifrey and Traken. I have no knowledge of these planets or their policies on Galactic Sector Council resolutions. Please enlighten me.
DOCTOR: We have no policy. It's no concern of ours that some
DOCTOR: might consider your actions here illegal. In fact, we barely understand the situation here on Veln.
NYSSA: All we know is that it's dangerous for us here, and we'd like to leave as soon as possible, please.
KOTEEM: If I could he sure that you were telling the truth, then I would let you go. But how can I be sure?
DOCTOR: Well, er, you could just try believing us.
KOTEEM: (laughs) You would advocate that I should trust you?
NYSSA: Yes. Is that so strange?
KOTEEM: Trust is a commodity in somewhat short supply in this sector of the galaxy.
DOCTOR: What a pity.
KOTEEM: Your bioscans and the way you speak indicate highly developed intelligence. You must have formed an opinion of our work here, even with the little knowledge you claim to have. I am attempting to trust you. Your hesitation is not reassuring me that I am wise to do so.
DOCTOR: Very well.
NYSSA: Doctor.
DOCTOR: They say honesty is the best policy, Nyssa.
NYSSA: And who precisely are they?
DOCTOR: It's either that or make a run for it, and somehow I don't think that's going to work.
KOTEEM: Your craft is held in a forcefield.
DOCTOR: You need hardly have said so.
KOTEEM: Do you have anything to say?
DOCTOR: Let me see. Now I've met you
KOTEEM: Yes?
NYSSA: Careful, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I think you have something in common with the people of Veln.
KOTEEM: And what would that be?
DOCTOR: Ooo, at a guess, dyestrial pollution.
DOCTOR: Sounds like I hit a sore spot.
SECURITY: [OC]: Charges set, sir.
GILBROOK: All right, people. Let's stand back. Oh, and you too, my Lady. Wouldn't want you to get a scratch on that beautiful face of yours.
FORLEON: I insist you contact your superiors. The terms of your warrant
GILBROOK: Shut up! That's better. All right, somebody press that button.
GILBROOK: Can we get the lights on in there?
FORLEON: Gilbrook, please, listen to me.
GILBROOK: Something to say?
FORLEON: You mustn't go in there.
GILBROOK: Oh, you're really scared, aren't you.
FORLEON: Look, I can't think of a better way to say this. You won't understand what you see in there.
GILBROOK: Oh dear, ugly and stupid, am I?
FORLEON: No, no, I didn't mean that. I
GILBROOK: Oh, just ugly, then.
FORLEON: Yes. Yes! You are ugly. Ugly and dying, all of you.
GILBROOK: Oh, now we hear it. So that makes you better than us, does it?
FORLEON: Yes. Because we have a chance at life. A chance to rebuild Veln. A chance to stop all the suffering.
GILBROOK: Well, you can do a lot with a pretty face in this world, darling, but you can't put right what those bastard Koteem did to us.
FORLEON: Please
GILBROOK: Do you really think a bit of cosmetic surgery's gonna mean you live longer, hey?
FORLEON: It isn't cosmetic surgery.
DOCTOR: So I gather your people, the Koteem ,suffered a planetary disaster involving some sort of dyestrial energy fusion plant.
KOTEEM: There was no disaster, only the decision to use dyestrial as our primary source of energy. By the time our medical scientists detected the genetic damage to our people, it was too late.
NYSSA: But how does that relate to the Veln?
KOTEEM: The story of what happened to the Veln is well known in this sector. Do you mean to claim that you have no knowledge of it? I find that hard to believe.
DOCTOR: Which makes it pretty pitiful as a lie, wouldn't you say?
NYSSA: All we do know is that the Veln government hold you responsible for the dyestrial pollution in their atmosphere, for the genetic and ecological damage caused here, and that you're trying to make amends.
KOTEEM: There was an accident.
DOCTOR: Accident?
KOTEEM: Our transport ships are forbidden to enter inhabited solar systems.
NYSSA: Transport ships? You mean ships transporting dyestrial waste?
KOTEEM: Highly dangerous toxins. Once the Koteem government had decided to phase out dyestrial power plants, the biggest problem was the disposal of these toxins. The Galactic Sector Council gave us permission to dispose of these toxins in uninhabited areas of the galaxy.
NYSSA: And you thought this solar system was uninhabited.
KOTEEM: No. Our people knew of the Veln, an undeveloped humanoid race only just beginning to venture beyond its planet.
DOCTOR: So you didn't bring your dyestrial waste here, so how
KOTEEM: Not officially.
DOCTOR: What do you mean?
KOTEEM: Avoiding the Veln solar system added a significant extra cost to those employed to dispose of the toxins. Their operations became more profitable if they deliberately ignored the fact that the occasional transport commander showed the initiative to
DOCTOR: Take a short cut. I see.
KOTEEM: There was an accident in high orbit above Veln. Dyestrial waste was released. The ship was destroyed. The planet was terminally polluted. That was four Veln generations ago. In another four generations, we, the Koteem, will be guilty of genocide.
DOCTOR: I see. And now you're planning to prevent that.
GILBROOK: Yeah, yeah, well keep her there. Right. Oh, and listen. Any word from the Ministry? Oh, thought as much. Well, senda message that I'll contact them as soon as I'm back at my office. I don't care if they don't like it, that's what I'm saying, all right? Good, because I think we've found ourselves all the evidence we need down here. Yeah. Right little chambers of horrors it is, too. Some of the stuff down here I, I think it's Koteem technology.
SECURITY: Sir.
GILBROOK: What have you got for me?
SECURITY: It's like a vid-record, only some kind of see-through ball thing. Our boys think they've worked out how to use it.
GILBROOK: Right, let's go.
FORLEON: [OC]: Veline, how are you feeling?
VELINE: [OC]: All right.
VELINE: I think I'm all right.
QUAIN: Just take a few deep breaths. You'll be fine. Pulse is a little high, that's all.
VELINE: Sorry, I'm being stupid, I know.
FORLEON: It's fine, Veline. Don't worry. Ready to start?
VELINE: Ready to start.
QUAIN: Good girl.
FORLEON: All right, Quain. Begin the procedure.
FORLEON: Are you ready, Quain?
QUAIN: Everything checks out.
FORLEON: Commence intramission.

elements.text: [Part Three]
It's all right, Veline. You're going to be all right.
What's happened?
She's having an abnormal reaction. I've only seen this happen once before..
Can you close?
I think, yes.
Zap, zap.
Closed.
Will she settle down now?
Let's hope so.
Veline screams.
Hold her, Quain! Hold her!
She's broken her
Crash!
No!
Beautiful.
Alarm sounds.
Oh ho ho, what have we got?
It's the basement alarm. Motion sensors have kicked in.
Motion sensors? You think we've got a break-in?
Call the basement.
Taps keys, phone rings.
[OC]: Forleon. Is that the guard room?
Yes, Lady Forleon.
[OC]: Have the motion sensors activated?
Yes, has someone
[OC]: It's Veline.
Veline? But
[OC]: She's had, she's had a bad reaction. She's broken out of the basement.
What's going on?
Just one moment please, Lady Forleon. It's Veline. She's gone berserk. She's the one tripping the sensors. Get the security camera views up. Find out where she is now.
I'm on it.
[OC]: Have you found her?
Murone?
Got her. She's in the grounds.
[OC]: What was that?
We've got her on camera, Lady Forleon. She's in the grounds.
What's that she's holding? Looks like a knife.
[OC]: She took a scalpel. Seedleson, where's she heading?
Murone, where's she heading?
By the sensors she's tripping, yeah, I'd say she's going straight for the main gate.
Did you hear that, Lady
[OC]: I heard.
What do I tell the boys at the main gate?
[OC]: Stop her but don't harm her. Understood?
Understood.
[OC]: Listen to me, Seedleson. That's most important. She was in mid-process. We musin't harm her.
Birds cawing. Running.
I can't. You're killing me. I can't do this. I can't. Suffocating. You're suffocating me. (cries)
Door closes.
If she gets out and anyone finds her
Just relax. It's not going to happen, Lady Forleon.
How can you be so sure? You were certain she'd survive the intramission, despite the early signs.
She has survived the intramission, with respect.
Never mind the respect. Are you saying we can complete the procedure? Well?
I don't know.
You said something about this happening before.
(sighs) Once, back in the beginning. But it wasn't like this.
How wasn't it like this?
The subject died, inside.
Telephone rings.
Get that.
Lady Forleon's study. Quain speaking. What? I see. Yes, well, that's all we need.
Phone down.
Is, is she dead?
No. I don't know. It wasn't about that.
What, then?
Perimeter scanners have picked up something.
What kind of something?
They don't know.
Oh, I don't believe this. All right, get Seedleson and Murone onto it. And you'd better make sure they're armed.
Telephone rings.
Gilbrook. What is it, I'm busy. At the Forleon Estate? Get a response vehicle there as quick as you can.
Telephone down.
(laughs) Oh, you beauty.
Patrol seven to Control. Hear me?
[OC]: Hear you.
Murone and me entering zone four. Still no sign of anything unusual.
[OC]: Understood. Keep searching.
Any word on Veline?
Oh, yeah. Any news on the runner?
[OC]: She bypassed the main gate.
What? Milady's gonna skin 'em alive for that. You mean they've totally lost track of Veline?
[OC]:They're after her now.
Rather them than me. All right, Control. Continue with search. See anything interesting with those things?
Yeah, I'm just focussing. Wait a moment.
Spotted something?
Take a look at that. Here.
Look at him, just wandering about.
Reckon he's Koteem?
Well, he's got weird clothes on, blond hair, and he's not as ugly as us. I reckon so.
We er, (sniffs) we could just shoot him.
Eh?
Yeah. Say he got panicked, made a run for the perimeter. We had no choice. You know, something like that. Bit of pay-back, you know, for what they did to us.
You're a vicious piece of work, aren't you, Murone?
Nothing wrong with a bit of pay-back.
These people are helping us now.
So they say.
So Lady Forleon says.
I don't trust them. I'll never trust them. If you ask me, she's crazy to have done what she did.
And she pays our wages.
All right. It's just a thought. Still, gives us any trouble, might shoot him by accident.
Why don't you just resign and go and work for the Security block?
No, this pays better.
Well, I must say, I do enjoy working alongside such a principled man as your good self, Murone.
Get stuffed. Well, let's go and reel him in.
Veline still crying out.
Hello? Who's there? It's all right. Don't be frightened. I'm not going to hurt you. What's your name?
Veline. I'm Veline.
Veline. Veline, put the knife down. You don't want to hurt yourself, do you.
Hurt myself?
Yes. Just drop it, down on the grass there, then you can tell me what the matter is.
Where's gone me?
I don't understand.
Me? There is no me.
What do you mean? Is someone chasing you? Is that why you were running?
No me.
Are you trying to get away from someone? Look, you're safe now.
Can't help me get away. It's suffocating me, it's strangling
me. Got to kill it.
What? Kill what? What do you mean.
Kill it!
No, Veline! No! Put the knife down. What are you doing? You'll hurt yourself.
Stab, Veline screams.
Veline, no! You mustn't!
Sirens approach.
Please don't stop me.
No, stop it. Let go! Let go of the knife!
Repeated slabs, Veline screams.
Please, no!
She kept stabbing herself. Over and over again. I couldn't stop her. I couldn't. It was horrible. Almost as if she was possessed. As if she thought there was something inside her
[OC]: She wanted to cut out.
So, what do you think? Crazy or what?
Why are you handing her over to me? Isn't this purely a security matter? Just the sort of thing you've been waiting for?
I want this to be watertight, Brodlik, so I need my top nutter expert in on this. And regrettably, that happens to be you.
Do you have the custody report? Thank you.
Nasty business.
Don't pretend to be concerned. They're both beauties, I heard.

The murderer and the murdered. I couldn't care less if those decadent gits start killing each other, but if it means an investigation of the Forleon Estate, then I am a very happy boy, Brodlik. The day we wipe the smug smile off that smug Forleon bitch's face will be a happy day for everyone in the world.
Turning pages.
So, one of them stabbed the other.
Yes, and luckily for us we nabbed them just before Forleon's security mob turned up. They were spitting blood. Mind you, So was she. (laughs)
Any idea of motive?
Well, that's what I need you for. She may be, well, a nutter.
What makes you say that?
Well, you saw her. Anyway, as well as generally looking pretty mad, they say she was using alien words.
What do you mean? We've got a Koteem in custody?
Could be.
Why don't we know for sure?

Oh, the medical boys are fannying around. I think they've messed up the blood test results. Said there was something not quite right. I dunno, usual excuses. I told them to get it right or lose their jobs. But as soon as they've run them again,
they'll let you Know. In the mean time, I want you to have a crack at her, see if you can find anything out. See if she is nuts.
It's unorthodox, but if you think it'll help.
Door shut, footsteps.
Brodlik, I'll be straight with you.
Sir?
I've never liked you.
I'm sorry to hear that, sir.

That's just what I mean. You're not sorry at all, because you don't like me either, do you. But you're good at your job. A bit over-conscientious, a bit namby-pamby for my liking, but you're top notch. What I'm saying is, Brodlik, you see me right on this one, I get promotion. I'm going places. And you'll be going with me. Understand?
That's most generous of you, sir.
Go on, get out of my sight. I want you to be the first person to see her the moment she's discharged from hospital.
Hospital?
A very messy business, murder. My officers are prone to get a little emotional when people with knives resist arrest.
I see.
Cold wind blowing. Footsteps indoors.
(sotto) Do you really believe that they're just going to let us get into the Tardis and go?
(sotto) I'm not sure. (normal) Er, these must be the travel pods the Koteem simulacrums land in.
That's right, Doctor. We ship them back up here periodically so that the Koteem can return them to their orbital space stations for reuse.
Recycling. How ecologically sound.
You still don't approve of us, do you.
Approve?
It's an invasion of sorts, isn't it?
It's survival.
Survival at any cost?
When the alternative is too horrible to contemplate. This whole situation is a, is a mess.
Now that I can whole-heartedly agree with.
But not with what we're doing here.
What the Koteem are doing here or what you're doing here. And exactly who or what are you, Quain? You, Forleon and the others.
We are the future of Veln.
So you said, Quain. So you said.
Walking
Where are you taking me?
I think we've heard enough from you for the moment, Sir.
Just as I suspected, Lady Forleon. Your hospitality is not exactly
Please, Doctor, this won't take long.
This way.
Er, that looks like an operating table.
Lie down, please, Doctor.
What are you going to do to me?
If you please, sir.
Very well. Now what?
Well, Quain?
What are we expecting, mental abnormality?
Or some sort of imposter from the Security block.
Do you think that's possible?
Up until now, I wouldn't have thought it was likely, but we have to be sure, don't we? After all, if we're not careful, we could be risking the future of the entire operation.
I'd rather you didn't use that word while I'm lying down here, if you don't mind. And considering I only came here to help you people, I
I'm warning you.
Calm down, Murone.
Sorry, Lady Forleon.
This isn't the Security block.
A level one scan should do it.
Proceed.
High pitched whine, the Doctor cries out.
Is this really necessary?
These readings are all wrong.
Doesn't that depend on what you're expecting to see?
And what do you think we're expecting to see?
You tell me.
None of the readings are consistent with a Koteem simulacrum.
A what simulacrum?
Switch off. You're not Koteem. Who are you?
Koteem. Koteem.
Are you trying to say you've never heard of the Koteem?
No, no, actually that's quite the opposite of what I'm trying to say, actually. Er, we're not doing very well on the communication front, are we.
So you have heard of the Koteem?
Well, I seem to remember the name. I may have read about them or I may have met them. Sometimes it's hard to remember. Ah. Aren't they extinct or something?
Extinct?

Ah, no. Probably the wrong thing to say. That probably happens later, doesn't it. Sorry. I can see I'd better shut up. I think that scan thing of yours has slightly scrambled my brain. What does it look for? Brainwave patterns, neuronic firing intervals, that
sort of thing? Perhaps you'd like me to have a look at Ow!
Just stay where you are and don't touch the equipment.
Sorry. Ah. That's it. I remember. The Koteem. An arthropod-like race from er, somewhere past Andromeda. Well, I say that, but if you take the first Galactic left after
Everyone knows about the Koteem.
Well, I should think that was highly unlikely, wouldn't you? I've only just remembered them at a pinch.
Everyone on this planet.
Yes, I see. And you were expecting me to be a Koteem.
Yes.

But that can't be right, can it? As I said, they're rather arthropod-like. You know, lots of legs, claws. And five eyes, I seem to remember. Or was it six? I think it varied from continent to continent. Can I get up now?
I'd rather you stayed there for now, Doctor.
I think I met one with seven eyes once. Yes, I do remember meeting them at a conference of some sort.
Well, Quain?
He is an alien.
But not a Koteem.
Well, they did warn us.
I can see it's a difficult concept for you to grasp. I'm sorry if I've spoiled your day.
Believe you me, Doctor, my day was spoilt long before you arrived.
Ah. The death of that girl. Veline, did you say?
Yes.
I was sorry to hear about that. How did she die? I take it you're not suggesting that my friend Nyssa actually did kill her?
No, we're not.
She almost certainly killed herself.
Why?
You should be more concerned with the fact that the Security people are never going to believe your friend is innocent.
Our people at the main gate inform me that your friend Nyssa?
Nyssa, yes.
She tried to help Veline. Her fingerprints will be all over the scalpel. And Security Chief Gilobrook will be only to pleased to put a beauty on trial for murder.
A beauty?
You really don't know anything about this planet at all, do you.
Except for the fact that it's shrouded in dangerous levels of dyestrial toxins, no. I've never come across Veln before.
Is he dangerous?
Scan shows a physiology broadly similar to that of a Veln. The organs seem completely displaced, but they're the same kinds
of organs performing the same kinds of functions, I'd guess. Blood pressure and heart rate are
Hearts. I have two.
Yes, I thought, I wondered what that was.
I'm guessing the short answer to my question is no. He's harmless.
I'd say that's fair. Nothing inherently dangerous about his physiology. We should perhaps check him for weapons.
Do that, and scan him again. Then bring him to my study.
That's it, then. They've really let us go.
Confusing, isn't it, when you don't know who the bad guys are?
Tardis door closes.
So much simpler when they have a satanic beard or black ears.
Has the Tardis recovered?
Er, yes. Yes, yes, I think we've been lucky, Nyssa.
You mean there was a possibility it wouldn't repair itself?

Nothing's ever certain with the Tardis. Now, the real trick is going to be hopping over that dyestrial cloud. I shall have to be certain we start moving in Time before we make the spatial shift. Could you check the power relays for me?
Of course. (beeps) Doctor?
Hmm? (beeps) What?
Is that it? Have you just forgotten about it all already?
No, but sometimes it doesn't do to dwell on things. (sigh) What's on your mind?
Did we change anything?
Do we ever?
Well, yes, don't we? Isn't that what you want to do? Isn't that why you said you left Gallifrey all those years ago, to make a difference?
Ah, the folly of youth.
You don't want to talk about it, do you.
That should do it. Want to give it a try?
Doctor!
Sometimes, if you stare at a painting for too long and get too close to it, all you can see are the brush strokes. The harder you stare, the more formless and meaningless it seems to become.
And that's your analogy for the whole of the universe, is it? A painting you don't want to look at too closely in case it doesn't mean anything.
Well. sometimes I think of it that way, yes. But if you're asking me if we made a difference on Veln, I really don't know.
But you wanted to make a difference, didn't you?
I suppose I had some good intentions after we landed.
You wanted to warn people about the pollution.

I had some time on my hands. I thought I'd try to use it fruitfully, but it turned out that they already knew about the pollution only to well. Four generations of bitter experience. Rather naive of me, I suppose. As for making a difference, I don't really think we influenced anything at all. If you hadn't found Veline, maybe someone else would have done. She would certainly have still killed herself. The Security people would still have had an excuse to raid Forleon's estate.
But when you and Quain rescued me from the Security block, you really stirred them up.
Yes, I know. We were lucky to get away with our lives.
Quick, Doctor, get it.
What's the hurry? The identity documents seemed to convince them. Shouldn't we keep calm and try not to attract any attention?
Up there, security camera moving towards us. It's giving me a bad feeling.
All right. Quickly, Nyssa. How are you feeling?
I'm fine. Let's just get out of here.
Vehicle doors slam.
Hey, stop!
They're onto us. Hold on tight.
Vehicle diesel engine starts.
Open fire!
Gunfire, vehicle roars off. Tyres screeching.
Come on, get out of the way.
Are we going to get out of this alive?
We've got a good head start, but they'll trace us straight back to the Estate eventually.
So where are we going to go?
We'll have to get there and warn them. Forleon will have to evacuate.
Evacuate? But
Don't worry. It was going to happen sooner or later. We've got contingency plans.
Which are?
Let's just say that after we've warned Forleon, we'll be going on a long trip, Dokter.
Look out!
Crash!
And if Quain hadn't been such a good driver, we wouldn't be here now.
Don't remind me. My leg still hurts. But as for our really affecting events in any meaningful way, I can't see how your being interrogated had any bearing on anything.
Just very unpleasant for me.
Sorry. Didn't mean to be insensitive.
It's all right. I Know what you're trying to say. And anyway,
when I heard Veline's screams, I should have gone straight back into the Tardis. Instead, I, well
You wanted to help, make a difference.
Yes. You're right. But what about the Veln and the Koteem? Who was right?
The Veln authorities tried to protect their people from what they saw as a terrible alien threat, or the Koteem trying to make amends in spite of the wishes of the Veln. Perhaps they were both right.
And both wrong.
Perhaps. But we were just swallowed up by the situation we fell into. I'm still not sure I entirely understand it myself. We had no control over anything.
Telephone slammed down.
Damn!
Who was that?
The Security Minister.
What did she say?
We can't move on Forleon's estate without clearer evidence.
I see. Why are you looking at me like that?
So you'd better tell me, hadn't you.
Tell you what?
Tell me the truth about those men who took this Nyssa girl out from under your nose. About the surveillance cameras cutting off.
I don't know what you mean.
Thump!
Ow! What're you doing? You can't do that. You can't Ow!
Breaking furniture. Stamp on flesh.
I can do anything I like, because I need you to tell me the truth and make a statement. I don't care what they threatened to do to you and your family.
Breaking small bones. Brodnik whimpers.
You know why I don't care?
No, no. Argh! Please don't. Argh!
Because whatever they said they'd do, I can do worse. These people are amateurs when it comes to intimidation. So, little Brodlik. (Big thump.) Start (crunch) Talking! (thump!)
We can only look forward, try not to judge too harshly, and do the best we can.
I suppose that's all we can do.
Or drive ourselves insane by staring at the brush strokes. Right, here we go.
The Tardis dematerialises.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
QUAIN: It's all right, Veline. You're going to be all right.
FORLEON: What's happened?
QUAIN: She's having an abnormal reaction. I've only seen this happen once before..
FORLEON: Can you close?
QUAIN: I think, yes.
QUAIN: Closed.
FORLEON: Will she settle down now?
QUAIN: Let's hope so.
FORLEON: Hold her, Quain! Hold her!
QUAIN: She's broken her
VELINE: No!
GILBROOK: Beautiful.
SEEDLESON: Oh ho ho, what have we got?
MURONE: It's the basement alarm. Motion sensors have kicked in.
SEEDLESON: Motion sensors? You think we've got a break-in?
MURONE: Call the basement.
FORLEON: [OC]: Forleon. Is that the guard room?
SEEDLESON: Yes, Lady Forleon.
FORLEON: [OC]: Have the motion sensors activated?
SEEDLESON: Yes, has someone
FORLEON: [OC]: It's Veline.
SEEDLESON: Veline? But
FORLEON: [OC]: She's had, she's had a bad reaction. She's broken out of the basement.
MURONE: What's going on?
SEEDLESON: Just one moment please, Lady Forleon. It's Veline. She's gone berserk. She's the one tripping the sensors. Get the security camera views up. Find out where she is now.
MURONE: I'm on it.
FORLEON: [OC]: Have you found her?
SEEDLESON: Murone?
MURONE: Got her. She's in the grounds.
FORLEON: [OC]: What was that?
SEEDLESON: We've got her on camera, Lady Forleon. She's in the grounds.
MURONE: What's that she's holding? Looks like a knife.
FORLEON: [OC]: She took a scalpel. Seedleson, where's she heading?
SEEDLESON: Murone, where's she heading?
MURONE: By the sensors she's tripping, yeah, I'd say she's going straight for the main gate.
SEEDLESON: Did you hear that, Lady
FORLEON: [OC]: I heard.
SEEDLESON: What do I tell the boys at the main gate?
FORLEON: [OC]: Stop her but don't harm her. Understood?
SEEDLESON: Understood.
FORLEON: [OC]: Listen to me, Seedleson. That's most important. She was in mid-process. We musin't harm her.
VELINE: I can't. You're killing me. I can't do this. I can't. Suffocating. You're suffocating me. (cries)
FORLEON: If she gets out and anyone finds her
QUAIN: Just relax. It's not going to happen, Lady Forleon.
FORLEON: How can you be so sure? You were certain she'd survive the intramission, despite the early signs.
QUAIN: She has survived the intramission, with respect.
FORLEON: Never mind the respect. Are you saying we can complete the procedure? Well?
QUAIN: I don't know.
FORLEON: You said something about this happening before.
QUAIN: (sighs) Once, back in the beginning. But it wasn't like this.
FORLEON: How wasn't it like this?
QUAIN: The subject died, inside.
FORLEON: Get that.
QUAIN: Lady Forleon's study. Quain speaking. What? I see. Yes, well, that's all we need.
FORLEON: Is, is she dead?
QUAIN: No. I don't know. It wasn't about that.
FORLEON: What, then?
QUAIN: Perimeter scanners have picked up something.
FORLEON: What kind of something?
QUAIN: They don't know.
FORLEON: Oh, I don't believe this. All right, get Seedleson and Murone onto it. And you'd better make sure they're armed.
GILBROOK: Gilbrook. What is it, I'm busy. At the Forleon Estate? Get a response vehicle there as quick as you can.
GILBROOK: (laughs) Oh, you beauty.
SEEDLESON: Patrol seven to Control. Hear me?
CONTROL: [OC]: Hear you.
SEEDLESON: Murone and me entering zone four. Still no sign of anything unusual.
CONTROL: [OC]: Understood. Keep searching.
MURONE: Any word on Veline?
SEEDLESON: Oh, yeah. Any news on the runner?
CONTROL: [OC]: She bypassed the main gate.
SEEDLESON: What? Milady's gonna skin 'em alive for that. You mean they've totally lost track of Veline?
CONTROL: [OC]:They're after her now.
SEEDLESON: Rather them than me. All right, Control. Continue with search. See anything interesting with those things?
MURONE: Yeah, I'm just focussing. Wait a moment.
SEEDLESON: Spotted something?
MURONE: Take a look at that. Here.
SEEDLESON: Look at him, just wandering about.
MURONE: Reckon he's Koteem?
SEEDLESON: Well, he's got weird clothes on, blond hair, and he's not as ugly as us. I reckon so.
MURONE: We er, (sniffs) we could just shoot him.
SEEDLESON: Eh?
MURONE: Yeah. Say he got panicked, made a run for the perimeter. We had no choice. You know, something like that. Bit of pay-back, you know, for what they did to us.
SEEDLESON: You're a vicious piece of work, aren't you, Murone?
MURONE: Nothing wrong with a bit of pay-back.
SEEDLESON: These people are helping us now.
MURONE: So they say.
SEEDLESON: So Lady Forleon says.
MURONE: I don't trust them. I'll never trust them. If you ask me, she's crazy to have done what she did.
SEEDLESON: And she pays our wages.
MURONE: All right. It's just a thought. Still, gives us any trouble, might shoot him by accident.
SEEDLESON: Why don't you just resign and go and work for the Security block?
MURONE: No, this pays better.
SEEDLESON: Well, I must say, I do enjoy working alongside such a principled man as your good self, Murone.
MURONE: Get stuffed. Well, let's go and reel him in.
NYSSA: Hello? Who's there? It's all right. Don't be frightened. I'm not going to hurt you. What's your name?
VELINE: Veline. I'm Veline.
NYSSA: Veline. Veline, put the knife down. You don't want to hurt yourself, do you.
VELINE: Hurt myself?
NYSSA: Yes. Just drop it, down on the grass there, then you can tell me what the matter is.
VELINE: Where's gone me?
NYSSA: I don't understand.
VELINE: Me? There is no me.
NYSSA: What do you mean? Is someone chasing you? Is that why you were running?
VELINE: No me.
NYSSA: Are you trying to get away from someone? Look, you're safe now.
VELINE: Can't help me get away. It's suffocating me, it's strangling
VELINE: me. Got to kill it.
NYSSA: What? Kill what? What do you mean.
VELINE: Kill it!
NYSSA: No, Veline! No! Put the knife down. What are you doing? You'll hurt yourself.
NYSSA: Veline, no! You mustn't!
VELINE: Please don't stop me.
NYSSA: No, stop it. Let go! Let go of the knife!
NYSSA: Please, no!
NYSSA: She kept stabbing herself. Over and over again. I couldn't stop her. I couldn't. It was horrible. Almost as if she was possessed. As if she thought there was something inside her
NYSSA: [OC]: She wanted to cut out.
GILBROOK: So, what do you think? Crazy or what?
BRODLIK: Why are you handing her over to me? Isn't this purely a security matter? Just the sort of thing you've been waiting for?
GILBROOK: I want this to be watertight, Brodlik, so I need my top nutter expert in on this. And regrettably, that happens to be you.
BRODLIK: Do you have the custody report? Thank you.
GILBROOK: Nasty business.
BRODLIK: Don't pretend to be concerned. They're both beauties, I heard.
GILBROOK: The murderer and the murdered. I couldn't care less if those decadent gits start killing each other, but if it means an investigation of the Forleon Estate, then I am a very happy boy, Brodlik. The day we wipe the smug smile off that smug Forleon bitch's face will be a happy day for everyone in the world.
BRODLIK: So, one of them stabbed the other.
GILBROOK: Yes, and luckily for us we nabbed them just before Forleon's security mob turned up. They were spitting blood. Mind you, So was she. (laughs)
BRODLIK: Any idea of motive?
GILBROOK: Well, that's what I need you for. She may be, well, a nutter.
BRODLIK: What makes you say that?
GILBROOK: Well, you saw her. Anyway, as well as generally looking pretty mad, they say she was using alien words.
BRODLIK: What do you mean? We've got a Koteem in custody?
GILBROOK: Could be.
BRODLIK: Why don't we know for sure?
GILBROOK: Oh, the medical boys are fannying around. I think they've messed up the blood test results. Said there was something not quite right. I dunno, usual excuses. I told them to get it right or lose their jobs. But as soon as they've run them again,
GILBROOK: they'll let you Know. In the mean time, I want you to have a crack at her, see if you can find anything out. See if she is nuts.
BRODLIK: It's unorthodox, but if you think it'll help.
GILBROOK: Brodlik, I'll be straight with you.
BRODLIK: Sir?
GILBROOK: I've never liked you.
BRODLIK: I'm sorry to hear that, sir.
GILBROOK: That's just what I mean. You're not sorry at all, because you don't like me either, do you. But you're good at your job. A bit over-conscientious, a bit namby-pamby for my liking, but you're top notch. What I'm saying is, Brodlik, you see me right on this one, I get promotion. I'm going places. And you'll be going with me. Understand?
BRODLIK: That's most generous of you, sir.
GILBROOK: Go on, get out of my sight. I want you to be the first person to see her the moment she's discharged from hospital.
BRODLIK: Hospital?
GILBROOK: A very messy business, murder. My officers are prone to get a little emotional when people with knives resist arrest.
BRODLIK: I see.
NYSSA: (sotto) Do you really believe that they're just going to let us get into the Tardis and go?
DOCTOR: (sotto) I'm not sure. (normal) Er, these must be the travel pods the Koteem simulacrums land in.
QUAIN: That's right, Doctor. We ship them back up here periodically so that the Koteem can return them to their orbital space stations for reuse.
DOCTOR: Recycling. How ecologically sound.
QUAIN: You still don't approve of us, do you.
DOCTOR: Approve?
NYSSA: It's an invasion of sorts, isn't it?
QUAIN: It's survival.
NYSSA: Survival at any cost?
QUAIN: When the alternative is too horrible to contemplate. This whole situation is a, is a mess.
DOCTOR: Now that I can whole-heartedly agree with.
QUAIN: But not with what we're doing here.
DOCTOR: What the Koteem are doing here or what you're doing here. And exactly who or what are you, Quain? You, Forleon and the others.
QUAIN: We are the future of Veln.
DOCTOR: So you said, Quain. So you said.
DOCTOR: Where are you taking me?
MURONE: I think we've heard enough from you for the moment, Sir.
DOCTOR: Just as I suspected, Lady Forleon. Your hospitality is not exactly
FORLEON: Please, Doctor, this won't take long.
QUAIN: This way.
DOCTOR: Er, that looks like an operating table.
QUAIN: Lie down, please, Doctor.
DOCTOR: What are you going to do to me?
MURONE: If you please, sir.
DOCTOR: Very well. Now what?
FORLEON: Well, Quain?
QUAIN: What are we expecting, mental abnormality?
FORLEON: Or some sort of imposter from the Security block.
QUAIN: Do you think that's possible?
FORLEON: Up until now, I wouldn't have thought it was likely, but we have to be sure, don't we? After all, if we're not careful, we could be risking the future of the entire operation.
DOCTOR: I'd rather you didn't use that word while I'm lying down here, if you don't mind. And considering I only came here to help you people, I
MURONE: I'm warning you.
FORLEON: Calm down, Murone.
MURONE: Sorry, Lady Forleon.
FORLEON: This isn't the Security block.
QUAIN: A level one scan should do it.
FORLEON: Proceed.
DOCTOR: Is this really necessary?
QUAIN: These readings are all wrong.
DOCTOR: Doesn't that depend on what you're expecting to see?
FORLEON: And what do you think we're expecting to see?
DOCTOR: You tell me.
QUAIN: None of the readings are consistent with a Koteem simulacrum.
DOCTOR: A what simulacrum?
FORLEON: Switch off. You're not Koteem. Who are you?
DOCTOR: Koteem. Koteem.
FORLEON: Are you trying to say you've never heard of the Koteem?
DOCTOR: No, no, actually that's quite the opposite of what I'm trying to say, actually. Er, we're not doing very well on the communication front, are we.
QUAIN: So you have heard of the Koteem?
DOCTOR: Well, I seem to remember the name. I may have read about them or I may have met them. Sometimes it's hard to remember. Ah. Aren't they extinct or something?
FORLEON: Extinct?
DOCTOR: Ah, no. Probably the wrong thing to say. That probably happens later, doesn't it. Sorry. I can see I'd better shut up. I think that scan thing of yours has slightly scrambled my brain. What does it look for? Brainwave patterns, neuronic firing intervals, that
DOCTOR: sort of thing? Perhaps you'd like me to have a look at Ow!
MURONE: Just stay where you are and don't touch the equipment.
DOCTOR: Sorry. Ah. That's it. I remember. The Koteem. An arthropod-like race from er, somewhere past Andromeda. Well, I say that, but if you take the first Galactic left after
QUAIN: Everyone knows about the Koteem.
DOCTOR: Well, I should think that was highly unlikely, wouldn't you? I've only just remembered them at a pinch.
FORLEON: Everyone on this planet.
DOCTOR: Yes, I see. And you were expecting me to be a Koteem.
QUAIN: Yes.
DOCTOR: But that can't be right, can it? As I said, they're rather arthropod-like. You know, lots of legs, claws. And five eyes, I seem to remember. Or was it six? I think it varied from continent to continent. Can I get up now?
FORLEON: I'd rather you stayed there for now, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I think I met one with seven eyes once. Yes, I do remember meeting them at a conference of some sort.
FORLEON: Well, Quain?
QUAIN: He is an alien.
FORLEON: But not a Koteem.
QUAIN: Well, they did warn us.
DOCTOR: I can see it's a difficult concept for you to grasp. I'm sorry if I've spoiled your day.
FORLEON: Believe you me, Doctor, my day was spoilt long before you arrived.
DOCTOR: Ah. The death of that girl. Veline, did you say?
QUAIN: Yes.
DOCTOR: I was sorry to hear about that. How did she die? I take it you're not suggesting that my friend Nyssa actually did kill her?
FORLEON: No, we're not.
QUAIN: She almost certainly killed herself.
DOCTOR: Why?
QUAIN: You should be more concerned with the fact that the Security people are never going to believe your friend is innocent.
FORLEON: Our people at the main gate inform me that your friend Nyssa?
DOCTOR: Nyssa, yes.
FORLEON: She tried to help Veline. Her fingerprints will be all over the scalpel. And Security Chief Gilobrook will be only to pleased to put a beauty on trial for murder.
DOCTOR: A beauty?
FORLEON: You really don't know anything about this planet at all, do you.
DOCTOR: Except for the fact that it's shrouded in dangerous levels of dyestrial toxins, no. I've never come across Veln before.
FORLEON: Is he dangerous?
QUAIN: Scan shows a physiology broadly similar to that of a Veln. The organs seem completely displaced, but they're the same kinds
QUAIN: of organs performing the same kinds of functions, I'd guess. Blood pressure and heart rate are
DOCTOR: Hearts. I have two.
QUAIN: Yes, I thought, I wondered what that was.
FORLEON: I'm guessing the short answer to my question is no. He's harmless.
QUAIN: I'd say that's fair. Nothing inherently dangerous about his physiology. We should perhaps check him for weapons.
FORLEON: Do that, and scan him again. Then bring him to my study.
NYSSA: That's it, then. They've really let us go.
DOCTOR: Confusing, isn't it, when you don't know who the bad guys are?
DOCTOR: So much simpler when they have a satanic beard or black ears.
NYSSA: Has the Tardis recovered?
DOCTOR: Er, yes. Yes, yes, I think we've been lucky, Nyssa.
NYSSA: You mean there was a possibility it wouldn't repair itself?
DOCTOR: Nothing's ever certain with the Tardis. Now, the real trick is going to be hopping over that dyestrial cloud. I shall have to be certain we start moving in Time before we make the spatial shift. Could you check the power relays for me?
NYSSA: Of course. (beeps) Doctor?
DOCTOR: Hmm? (beeps) What?
NYSSA: Is that it? Have you just forgotten about it all already?
DOCTOR: No, but sometimes it doesn't do to dwell on things. (sigh) What's on your mind?
NYSSA: Did we change anything?
DOCTOR: Do we ever?
NYSSA: Well, yes, don't we? Isn't that what you want to do? Isn't that why you said you left Gallifrey all those years ago, to make a difference?
DOCTOR: Ah, the folly of youth.
NYSSA: You don't want to talk about it, do you.
DOCTOR: That should do it. Want to give it a try?
NYSSA: Doctor!
DOCTOR: Sometimes, if you stare at a painting for too long and get too close to it, all you can see are the brush strokes. The harder you stare, the more formless and meaningless it seems to become.
NYSSA: And that's your analogy for the whole of the universe, is it? A painting you don't want to look at too closely in case it doesn't mean anything.
DOCTOR: Well. sometimes I think of it that way, yes. But if you're asking me if we made a difference on Veln, I really don't know.
NYSSA: But you wanted to make a difference, didn't you?
DOCTOR: I suppose I had some good intentions after we landed.
NYSSA: You wanted to warn people about the pollution.
DOCTOR: I had some time on my hands. I thought I'd try to use it fruitfully, but it turned out that they already knew about the pollution only to well. Four generations of bitter experience. Rather naive of me, I suppose. As for making a difference, I don't really think we influenced anything at all. If you hadn't found Veline, maybe someone else would have done. She would certainly have still killed herself. The Security people would still have had an excuse to raid Forleon's estate.
NYSSA: But when you and Quain rescued me from the Security block, you really stirred them up.
DOCTOR: Yes, I know. We were lucky to get away with our lives.
QUAIN: Quick, Doctor, get it.
DOCTOR: What's the hurry? The identity documents seemed to convince them. Shouldn't we keep calm and try not to attract any attention?
QUAIN: Up there, security camera moving towards us. It's giving me a bad feeling.
DOCTOR: All right. Quickly, Nyssa. How are you feeling?
NYSSA: I'm fine. Let's just get out of here.
SECURITY: Hey, stop!
QUAIN: They're onto us. Hold on tight.
SECURITY: Open fire!
QUAIN: Come on, get out of the way.
NYSSA: Are we going to get out of this alive?
QUAIN: We've got a good head start, but they'll trace us straight back to the Estate eventually.
DOCTOR: So where are we going to go?
QUAIN: We'll have to get there and warn them. Forleon will have to evacuate.
DOCTOR: Evacuate? But
QUAIN: Don't worry. It was going to happen sooner or later. We've got contingency plans.
DOCTOR: Which are?
QUAIN: Let's just say that after we've warned Forleon, we'll be going on a long trip, Dokter.
NYSSA: Look out!
NYSSA: And if Quain hadn't been such a good driver, we wouldn't be here now.
DOCTOR: Don't remind me. My leg still hurts. But as for our really affecting events in any meaningful way, I can't see how your being interrogated had any bearing on anything.
NYSSA: Just very unpleasant for me.
DOCTOR: Sorry. Didn't mean to be insensitive.
NYSSA: It's all right. I Know what you're trying to say. And anyway,
NYSSA: when I heard Veline's screams, I should have gone straight back into the Tardis. Instead, I, well
DOCTOR: You wanted to help, make a difference.
NYSSA: Yes. You're right. But what about the Veln and the Koteem? Who was right?
DOCTOR: The Veln authorities tried to protect their people from what they saw as a terrible alien threat, or the Koteem trying to make amends in spite of the wishes of the Veln. Perhaps they were both right.
NYSSA: And both wrong.
DOCTOR: Perhaps. But we were just swallowed up by the situation we fell into. I'm still not sure I entirely understand it myself. We had no control over anything.
GILBROOK: Damn!
BRODLIK: Who was that?
GILBROOK: The Security Minister.
BRODLIK: What did she say?
GILBROOK: We can't move on Forleon's estate without clearer evidence.
BRODLIK: I see. Why are you looking at me like that?
GILBROOK: So you'd better tell me, hadn't you.
BRODLIK: Tell you what?
GILBROOK: Tell me the truth about those men who took this Nyssa girl out from under your nose. About the surveillance cameras cutting off.
BRODLIK: I don't know what you mean.
BRODLIK: Ow! What're you doing? You can't do that. You can't Ow!
GILBROOK: I can do anything I like, because I need you to tell me the truth and make a statement. I don't care what they threatened to do to you and your family.
GILBROOK: You know why I don't care?
BRODNIK: No, no. Argh! Please don't. Argh!
GILBROOK: Because whatever they said they'd do, I can do worse. These people are amateurs when it comes to intimidation. So, little Brodlik. (Big thump.) Start (crunch) Talking! (thump!)
DOCTOR: We can only look forward, try not to judge too harshly, and do the best we can.
NYSSA: I suppose that's all we can do.
DOCTOR: Or drive ourselves insane by staring at the brush strokes. Right, here we go.

elements.text: [Part Four]
[OC]: This is Captain Delarphim to all decks. Secure for silent running. We are entering the Veln system, and as you well know, we must not be detected.
The speakers are Koteem.
All external transmitters must be shut down. Power emissions are to be kept at absolute minimum until we clear the system. That is all. Pilot, increase speed to maximum.
Increasing.
Alarm sounds.
What is that?
A power leak on aft section toxin containment fields.
Shut it off immediately!
Shutting it off will mean the toxin containment fields will be weakened.
Space travel is not allowed in this solar system, or were you forgetting that fact? We are therefore hardly likely to collide with anything, are we? Shut it off, pilot.
Tardis console beeping.
Those power relays seem fine now.
Fine one moment, not so fine the next. One minute everything seems perfectly under control and the next? (beeps) Sorry, old girl, didn't mean to hurt your feelings.
That was another fluctuation in the relays.
Which rather illustrates my point, unfortunately.
I distinctly remember you talking about arranging some kind of overhaul for the Tardis.
Yes. Yes, I do that from time to time, don't I?
Talk about it, but don't get round to it, you mean.
Yes. Shall we see if your repairs have worked?
I see.
What?
Nothing. Ready when you are, Doctor.
So, we're drifting forwards in time at a rate of oh, quite slowly, really. Now where are we?
It's coming up as the Veln solar system.
Veln? Veln. Veln, Veln. No, never heard of it. Do we have any information in the Tardis databank?
I'll have a look. Er, planet Veln. Nothing much here. Diagrams of landmasses, population totals listed for several centuries. Oh, what's this? Galactic Sector Council resolution 4416.
What does it say?
Planet Veln on the brink of developing rudimentary space travel. Currently off-limits to all interplanetary space flight.
Currently? That must relate to the time period we're currently traversing. The database wouldn't have come up with it,
otherwise. Good.
Why? Because there won't be much traffic around?
Exactly. We can effect a nice safe materialisation in space to check the power relays. Keep an eye on the relay monitor while I do this, please. Now, nice and slowly does it. So far, so good.
The Tardis materialises. Beeping.
That's the helmic regulator.
Just slipping a little. Can you compensate?
Just about. We've drifted into Veln orbit.
Shouldn't be a problem. (engines stop) There.
Everything seems normal.
Good. Well, let's dematerialise again.
Alarm sounds.
That doesn't sound very encouraging.
Blue and yellow flashing together. What does that mean? Ah! Ah, yes, Yes, the outer shell of the Tardis is reacting to some sort of toxin.
It says dyestrium.
Dyestrium? Very nasty indeed. What's dyestrium doing in orbit around Veln? We'd better get out of here.
The Tardis engines start, then zap!
Ah! You all right?
(coughing) Just about. Looks like the console is going to catch fire.
She'll be all right.
Bang!
Doesn't sound all right.
Dyestrium is affecting the power relays.
It sounded like we hit something.
No, nothing out there to hit, just a few
stationary primitive orbital platforms, that's all. Ah, there, that's better. We're drifting forwards in time a little, a century or so.
We're landing again.
So we are. And still reading high levels of dyestrium. Not as high as before, but still lethal.
The Tardis materialises.
Where are we?
Scanner.
All looks rather pleasant, doesn't it?
This is the planet Veln.
Hmm. Doesn't look like it's heavily polluted with dyestrium, does it? Ah yes, but look. There's still a high degree of airborne toxins.
Er, Doctor, why did we land?
Emergency materialisation. The Tardis needs to repair the damage to the relays.
Is this the ideal place for the Tardis to do that, given that there's dyestrium in the atmosphere, and it was dyestrium that caused the problem in the first place?
I'm afraid we don't have any choice. The old girl's shut down her systems. We'll just have to wait for her to finish the repairs on her own. Care for a walk?
Are you sure it's safe?

The atmosphere is certainly breathable. It'll only be dangerous for us if we suffer prolonged exposure, and we're not staying long. And it doesn't look like anybody's about. We might as well. Come on.
Tardis door opens.
It's a nice day. Reminds me of home in some ways.
What's that over there in the distance?
Er, a building of some sort, isn't it?
Yes. Where are my binoculars? Ah, here we are. Hmm. Beautiful architecture. The product of a very civilised mind, I should say. Hmm.
You're not thinking we should go and take a look?
No.
Good.
No, I'm thinking / should go and take a look, and you should stay here and keep an eye on the Tardis repairs. She may need some prompting from time to time.
Doctor, how do you know the people here are friendly?
Beautiful architecture is invariably a sign of a friendly temperament.
And now you're talking rubbish.

Perhaps, but I'll just go and take a look. Perhaps I'll be able to warn them about the dangers of using dyestrium as a basis for energy production. You know, just push them gently in the right direction. Suggest the ionisation of hydrogen or something like that.
I can see there's no point arguing with you.
(receding) Stay close to the Tardis. Won't be long.
Typical.
A woman cries out in the distance.
What was that?

Mmm. Mmm. She is a beauty, isn't she? Aren't you, Veline, eh? Lovely nose, lovely, oh, everything. Lovely Veline. I know plenty of people who'd give their left arm for a nose like that. (chuckles) Oh, yes. So, at a guess, I'd say multiple stab wounds?
Must you?
Watch it.
Sorry, sir. It's actually a peculiar methodology.
The one we've got in custody just stabbed her to death. What's peculiar about that?
But the angle and pressure points of the wounds indicate. I'm not sure.
Spit it out.
Well, almost as if the murderer were trying to
Trying to what?
Dig something out rather than just kill the victim.
That confirms what I've always said about Forleon's lot.
What's that?
Those people are weird.
Well, Quain, now you're certain I'm not inherently dangerous and that I don't have any weapons on me, perhaps you'd like to tell me exactly what you do here?
The Lady Forleon wants to see you. You can ask her as many questions as you like. Of course, I can't guarantee that she'll answer any of them.

Don't want to talk out of turn. I see. You're a conscientious employee. Very admirable. Then let me guess. This apparatus is for some kind of surgical implantation, isn't it? Ah. I see I'm on the right track. But what about the simulacrum, Isn't that what you said? Koteem simulacrum. A simulacrum is a likeness of something, isn't it? A substitute, a kind of copy. So what would a Koteem's simulacrum be? A copy of a Koteem? Hardly likely, since you thought I was one, and I'm certainly not an arthropod.
All right, that's enough. Come with me.
So logically this simulacrum would be a copy of something that looks humanoid. Something that could be mistaken for a Veln.
This way, Doctor.
I'd be delighted.
He is totally alien. Not Veln, not Koteem.
[OC]: Have his actions been hostile?
No. He seems to know nothing about our operations here.
[OC]: He may be working for the Koteem government or the Galactic Sector Council. He may be trying to sabotage our work.
My instincts tell me that isn't the case. He appears to be genuinely ignorant.
[OC]: I trust your instincts, Lady Forleon, but perhaps it would be best if he is brought to me as soon as is convenient.
Very well. But there is one other thing.
[OC]: Please elaborate.
This Dokter has a friend, a girl. She somehow got mixed up with the death of Veline. Gilbrook and his people have charged her with murder.
[OC]: If this girl were to talk openly to Veln security, she may cause an increasing paranoia within the Security department.
If that's possible.
[OC]: She must be retrieved. I will leave that in your capable hands, Lady Forleon.
Beeping.
Er, Quain is bringing this Dokter to me now.
[OC]: Very well. My thoughts are with you. Ending communication.
Knock on door.
Come.
Door opens.
Lady Forleon
You'll be relieved to hear that I apparently don't pose you any clear and present danger.
I shall be the judge of that, Dokter. Please, sit down.
Thank you.
Where are you from?
I am from the planet Gallifrey, and my companion Nyssa is from Traken. Forgive me, but I'm sure you're none the wiser.
You obviously regard us as some sort of inferior species.
No. Less technologically developed, and with no real experience of life outside your own world, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. You and I are just different.
How very magnanimous of you. Why have you come to our planet?
We are simply travellers. We're here by accident. My craft was adversely affected by the dyestrial pollution in your atmosphere. I was forced to land here in order for my craft
The Tardis.
Yes, it is called the Tardis. I didn't make that up. In for the Tardis to affect repairs to itself.
Your craft can repair itself?
Yes. Look, all we want to do is leave. We didn't want to get involved with your affairs. I just want to find Nyssa and leave with her.

If you didn't want to become involve in our affairs, why did you come here, to this house? Couldn't you have just stayed in your craft until it had repaired itself? Is this line of questioning irritating you?
Only because you're reminding me of Nyssa.
You find your companion irritating.
Yes. Especially when she's right. I shouldn't have come here. I wanted to warn you about the dyestrium.
We already know about the dyestrium.

Yes, I know, and I should have known that. I should have known (pause) better. The truth is, I let my curiosity get the better of me. I know it sounds stupid now, but I admired the architecture of this building, I wanted to meet the people who built it.
And warn us about the dyestrium.
Yes, I did. Look, I don't expect you to believe me. All I'm interested in is finding Nyssa. What do your security people do to those people they accuse of murder?
They execute them, in one of several very unpleasant ways.
In which case I'm begging you to let me try to rescue her.
You wouldn't survive a day out there in the city.
Then will you help me?
As a matter of fact, we will.
Thank you.
Lady Forleon?
We have to, Quain.
I understand.
Do you have any reports on her whereabouts?
Last we'd heard, she'd been taken to the Central Hospital.
Hospital?
Our Security block personnel are not known for their subtlety, Dokter.
So you said. How soon can we get to her?
Quain?
I'll start setting things up.
If there's anything I can do to help.
Leave it to the professionals, Dokter.
Door closes.
I don't wish to seem ungrateful, but I take it you're helping me because Nyssa being arrested has somehow jeopardised your plans.
That's right.
And what are your plans?
For someone who isn't interested in the affairs of this planet
Ah! Well, you see, that's my curiosity again. I just don't seem to be able to keep it under control. What's your relationship with the Koteem?
You'll find out, when you meet them.
I see. You're obviously working for them, leaving the big decisions to them. Always a mistake, in my experience, working for a more technologically advanced species.
We are not working for them.
No? But they're giving you something you need, aren't they? Something concealed inside a simulacrum. A facsimile of a Veln. How am I doing?

This isn't some intellectual puzzle. You're treating issues concerning the survival of civilisation on this planet as a child's guessing game. Is that what you do, travel around the galaxy making light of other people's problems?
I'm not making light of them, I'm trying to understand them.
So that you can interfere, give us the benefit of your superior knowledge? Isn't it enough that Veln has been all but destroyed by one alien species without another making things worse?
The Koteem destroyed? What has happened here, Lady Forleon?

You haven't seen beyond this estate, have you? I was lucky enough to be borne into a rich family. My mother had this place built when everything around her was falling apart. The economy, society, even the people themselves.
The effects of dyestrial pollution.

That's right. The end of agriculture, the collapse of food production, global economic meltdown. Poverty and endemic crime. Every nation on this planet labours under paranoid government security measures and institutionalised corruption. Our civilisation isn't dying. It's already dead. All that's left is the rotting corpse. My mother saw it happening, and the only way she could cope was to use as much of her power and influence as she could to shut it out.

So she lived here in her own personal paradise. But that wasn't good enough for you, was it, Lady Forleon? Tell me, why do you and Quain look so different from your henchman? Murone, I believe I heard you call him?
Most people on this planet look like Murone. The pollution caused some kind of genetic illness. There's no cure.
Except the one the Koteem are offering you.
It isn't a cure.
Oh?
It's less than that. Although, in some ways, it's more.
Commence intramission.
Zap! Squelch.
Intramission successful. The Koteem mass is integrating. Genetic structure alterations commencing.
I never tire of this moment. It's like a miracle, a beautiful miracle. Like generations of disease and ugliness burned away from within.
The Koteem are giving you their essence. I'm not sure I understand.

I'd invested all my family's money in research into a cure. The funds were just pouring away. Every line of research was a blind alley. We started experimenting with the benefits of zero gravity for treatment. We took patients up into an orbital satellite I'd bought off a government. Oh, they were always keen to take my money. Ridiculed me in public, but took my money behind closed doors.
And the Koteem contacted you, didn't they?
They did.

High orbital above Veln. Dyestrial waste was released. The ship was destroyed. The planet was terminally polluted. That was four Veln generations ago. In another four generations, we, the Koteem, will be guilty of genocide.
I see. And now you're planning to prevent that.
My people had experimented with isolating that which made us what we were.
Your essence.
As our bodies decayed, we attempted to transplant this essence into artificial survival units. But it was useless. The essence could not survive.
So you thought you'd use the Veln as your new bodies.
Our government offered many ideas for reparation to the people of Veln. They rejected everything we offered. They became paranoid, war-like.
Understandably. You had condemned their planet to a long, lingering death.
We knew that only too well, as we had condemned ourselves to death. Eventually, the Galactic Sector Council declared all contact with Veln illegal.
You mean, you're not official?
Our government have dismissed us as extremists and fanatics. They say we are attempting to create a hybrid race.
Isn't that what you're doing?
We have discovered that the Koteem essence strengthens the Veln genetic structure.
And you're sacrificing Koteem lives to do this?
All of us within our organisation hope to make that sacrifice.
Two doomed races joined to create a new one. It's an interesting notion. A thorny ethical issue, though.
We value the sanctity of life so much that we are prepared to change the nature of life itself so that it may continue. You may view us as either fanatics or the saviours of two races.
But aren't you forcing the Veln to become, well, surrogate Koteem?
No one is forced. And in truth, very little of the Koteem remains after the process. Very occasionally, a subject rejects the implantation. We bitterly regret such occurances.
That won't bring Veline back from the dead.
Some might say you're attempting to play god.

All races evolve and develop. Why should not that evolution, that quest for survival, be scientifically introduced? Or should both races suffer because of the sins of their forefathers? Isn't it time to break with the past?
But shouldn't both races as a whole choose to do this?
Both governments are blinded by prejudice.
Have you thought that it might be you who are blind?
I wouldn't want to be in your position, to have to make that choice.
Neither would I.
If the Koteem or Veln governments were to hear of our operation, it would be the end for both civilisations.
It is the end, though, isn't it?
Or the birth of a new one. We won't tell anyone. It's not our place to interfere.
You may go.
Over the sound of the Tardis dematerialing.
You see ugliness when you look at my face. When you look at the face of most people in the world. Distorted skin tissue, abnormal bone structure.
Our civilisation isn't dying. It's already dead. All that's left is the rotting corpse.
Should both races suffer because of the sins of their forefathers?
Quain. Lady Forleon has been relocated. You must join her and restart the operation.
Of course. Gilbrook and his men will have torn apart everything on the estate.
Will our plans be compromised?
They won't be able to make head nor tail of it. It's beyond them.
Let us hope so. However, I will relocate this ship. Your security people may find something on the estate which can lead them to it.
Glad to see you've still got the security of the operation at heart.
What is troubling you?
The two strangers. You, you just let them go!
Yes.
You trusted them?
You think I was foolish?
I think you took an unnecessary risk.
Trust is always a risk. Did not you and Lady Forleon take a risk in trusting me all those years ago?
Point taken.
Diesel engine rattling.
This is Chief Gilbrook to all assault vehicles. Stand by. We're now approaching the location of suspected Koteem incursion. Bring all weapons to bear.
Engine stops.
This is it, sir.
Brodlik, give me the map.
Cold wind blowing.
I don't know why you had to drag me half way across the world.
You're my star witness, Brodlik. I want to keep an eye on you. And anyway, when we get our hands on those alien scum, I want to know what makes them tick, and you're just the man to find out.
I'm not qualified to work on aliens.
Don't remind me. This is definitely it. You see? Matches the grid reference we found in Forleon's files.
There's nothing here.
No. No, there isn't, is there.
No.
Which means we have to start again, Brodlik.
Start what again?

I know there's Koteem on this planet. I feel it in my aching bones, Brodlik. And if it takes the rest of my miserable life, I shall not lay down and die until I make sure the filthy aliens have finally left us alone! You know something, Brodlik?
What?
My great-grandfather was just a kid working in the fields when it happened.
When what happened?

Fields. Can you imagine that? Huge areas of land where crops would grow. Crops that could feed thousands of people. And my great-granddad, he looked up into the sky and saw it and so he told his son, and so he told my dad, he saw that Koteem ship explode. He saw it. He said it was like paint spilling across a table. It seemed at first, he said, he said it was almost beautiful.
Alarm.
Pilot, what is that?
An object has just appeared dead ahead of us. Cuboid, high mass and energy.
Full avoidance procedures. Emergency thrust.
The object appears to be emitting some kind of warp distortion field.
But it is stationary.
Captain, it has disappeared.
Alarm.
What is happening now?
Toxin containers have smashed in the aft section.
What about the containment fields?
You ordered them shut down. The hull is breaking up.
No!
There was an accident in high orbit above Veln. Dyestrial waste was released. The ship was destroyed. The planet was terminally polluted. That was four Veln generations ago.
KaBOOM! and Tardis engines.
As for making a difference, I don't really think we influenced anything at all.
The explosion reverberates.
Beautiful.

DELARPHIM: [OC]: This is Captain Delarphim to all decks. Secure for silent running. We are entering the Veln system, and as you well know, we must not be detected.
DELARPHIM: All external transmitters must be shut down. Power emissions are to be kept at absolute minimum until we clear the system. That is all. Pilot, increase speed to maximum.
PILOT: Increasing.
DELARPHIM: What is that?
PILOT: A power leak on aft section toxin containment fields.
DELARPHIM: Shut it off immediately!
PILOT: Shutting it off will mean the toxin containment fields will be weakened.
DELARPHIM: Space travel is not allowed in this solar system, or were you forgetting that fact? We are therefore hardly likely to collide with anything, are we? Shut it off, pilot.
NYSSA: Those power relays seem fine now.
DOCTOR: Fine one moment, not so fine the next. One minute everything seems perfectly under control and the next? (beeps) Sorry, old girl, didn't mean to hurt your feelings.
NYSSA: That was another fluctuation in the relays.
DOCTOR: Which rather illustrates my point, unfortunately.
NYSSA: I distinctly remember you talking about arranging some kind of overhaul for the Tardis.
DOCTOR: Yes. Yes, I do that from time to time, don't I?
NYSSA: Talk about it, but don't get round to it, you mean.
DOCTOR: Yes. Shall we see if your repairs have worked?
NYSSA: I see.
DOCTOR: What?
NYSSA: Nothing. Ready when you are, Doctor.
DOCTOR: So, we're drifting forwards in time at a rate of oh, quite slowly, really. Now where are we?
NYSSA: It's coming up as the Veln solar system.
DOCTOR: Veln? Veln. Veln, Veln. No, never heard of it. Do we have any information in the Tardis databank?
NYSSA: I'll have a look. Er, planet Veln. Nothing much here. Diagrams of landmasses, population totals listed for several centuries. Oh, what's this? Galactic Sector Council resolution 4416.
DOCTOR: What does it say?
NYSSA: Planet Veln on the brink of developing rudimentary space travel. Currently off-limits to all interplanetary space flight.
DOCTOR: Currently? That must relate to the time period we're currently traversing. The database wouldn't have come up with it,
DOCTOR: otherwise. Good.
NYSSA: Why? Because there won't be much traffic around?
DOCTOR: Exactly. We can effect a nice safe materialisation in space to check the power relays. Keep an eye on the relay monitor while I do this, please. Now, nice and slowly does it. So far, so good.
NYSSA: That's the helmic regulator.
DOCTOR: Just slipping a little. Can you compensate?
NYSSA: Just about. We've drifted into Veln orbit.
DOCTOR: Shouldn't be a problem. (engines stop) There.
NYSSA: Everything seems normal.
DOCTOR: Good. Well, let's dematerialise again.
NYSSA: That doesn't sound very encouraging.
DOCTOR: Blue and yellow flashing together. What does that mean? Ah! Ah, yes, Yes, the outer shell of the Tardis is reacting to some sort of toxin.
NYSSA: It says dyestrium.
DOCTOR: Dyestrium? Very nasty indeed. What's dyestrium doing in orbit around Veln? We'd better get out of here.
DOCTOR: Ah! You all right?
NYSSA: (coughing) Just about. Looks like the console is going to catch fire.
DOCTOR: She'll be all right.
NYSSA: Doesn't sound all right.
DOCTOR: Dyestrium is affecting the power relays.
NYSSA: It sounded like we hit something.
DOCTOR: No, nothing out there to hit, just a few
DOCTOR: stationary primitive orbital platforms, that's all. Ah, there, that's better. We're drifting forwards in time a little, a century or so.
NYSSA: We're landing again.
DOCTOR: So we are. And still reading high levels of dyestrium. Not as high as before, but still lethal.
NYSSA: Where are we?
DOCTOR: All looks rather pleasant, doesn't it?
NYSSA: This is the planet Veln.
DOCTOR: Hmm. Doesn't look like it's heavily polluted with dyestrium, does it? Ah yes, but look. There's still a high degree of airborne toxins.
NYSSA: Er, Doctor, why did we land?
DOCTOR: Emergency materialisation. The Tardis needs to repair the damage to the relays.
NYSSA: Is this the ideal place for the Tardis to do that, given that there's dyestrium in the atmosphere, and it was dyestrium that caused the problem in the first place?
DOCTOR: I'm afraid we don't have any choice. The old girl's shut down her systems. We'll just have to wait for her to finish the repairs on her own. Care for a walk?
NYSSA: Are you sure it's safe?
DOCTOR: The atmosphere is certainly breathable. It'll only be dangerous for us if we suffer prolonged exposure, and we're not staying long. And it doesn't look like anybody's about. We might as well. Come on.
NYSSA: It's a nice day. Reminds me of home in some ways.
DOCTOR: What's that over there in the distance?
NYSSA: Er, a building of some sort, isn't it?
DOCTOR: Yes. Where are my binoculars? Ah, here we are. Hmm. Beautiful architecture. The product of a very civilised mind, I should say. Hmm.
NYSSA: You're not thinking we should go and take a look?
DOCTOR: No.
NYSSA: Good.
DOCTOR: No, I'm thinking / should go and take a look, and you should stay here and keep an eye on the Tardis repairs. She may need some prompting from time to time.
NYSSA: Doctor, how do you know the people here are friendly?
DOCTOR: Beautiful architecture is invariably a sign of a friendly temperament.
NYSSA: And now you're talking rubbish.
DOCTOR: Perhaps, but I'll just go and take a look. Perhaps I'll be able to warn them about the dangers of using dyestrium as a basis for energy production. You know, just push them gently in the right direction. Suggest the ionisation of hydrogen or something like that.
NYSSA: I can see there's no point arguing with you.
DOCTOR: (receding) Stay close to the Tardis. Won't be long.
NYSSA: Typical.
NYSSA: What was that?
GILBROOK: Mmm. Mmm. She is a beauty, isn't she? Aren't you, Veline, eh? Lovely nose, lovely, oh, everything. Lovely Veline. I know plenty of people who'd give their left arm for a nose like that. (chuckles) Oh, yes. So, at a guess, I'd say multiple stab wounds?
ATTENDANT: Must you?
GILBROOK: Watch it.
ATTENDANT: Sorry, sir. It's actually a peculiar methodology.
GILBROOK: The one we've got in custody just stabbed her to death. What's peculiar about that?
ATTENDANT: But the angle and pressure points of the wounds indicate. I'm not sure.
GILBROOK: Spit it out.
ATTENDANT: Well, almost as if the murderer were trying to

ATTENDANT: Dig something out rather than just kill the victim.
GILBROOK: That confirms what I've always said about Forleon's lot.
ATTENDANT: What's that?
GILBROOK: Those people are weird.
DOCTOR: Well, Quain, now you're certain I'm not inherently dangerous and that I don't have any weapons on me, perhaps you'd like to tell me exactly what you do here?
QUAIN: The Lady Forleon wants to see you. You can ask her as many questions as you like. Of course, I can't guarantee that she'll answer any of them.

KOTEEM: Quain. Lady Forleon has been relocated. You must join her and restart the operation.
QUAIN: Of course. Gilbrook and his men will have torn apart everything on the estate.
KOTEEM: Will our plans be compromised?
QUAIN: They won't be able to make head nor tail of it. It's beyond them.
KOTEEM: Let us hope so. However, I will relocate this ship. Your security people may find something on the estate which can lead them to it.
QUAIN: Glad to see you've still got the security of the operation at heart.
KOTEEM: What is troubling you?
QUAIN: The two strangers. You, you just let them go!
KOTEEM: Yes.
QUAIN: You trusted them?
KOTEEM: You think I was foolish?
QUAIN: I think you took an unnecessary risk.
KOTEEM: Trust is always a risk. Did not you and Lady Forleon take a risk in trusting me all those years ago?
QUAIN: Point taken.
GILBROOK: This is Chief Gilbrook to all assault vehicles. Stand by. We're now approaching the location of suspected Koteem incursion. Bring all weapons to bear.
DRIVER: This is it, sir.
GILBROOK: Brodlik, give me the map.
BRODLIK: I don't know why you had to drag me half way across the world.
GILBROOK: You're my star witness, Brodlik. I want to keep an eye on you. And anyway, when we get our hands on those alien scum, I want to know what makes them tick, and you're just the man to find out.
BRODLIK: I'm not qualified to work on aliens.
GILBROOK: Don't remind me. This is definitely it. You see? Matches the grid reference we found in Forleon's files.
BRODLIK: There's nothing here.
GILBROOK: No. No, there isn't, is there.
BRODLIK: No.
GILBROOK: Which means we have to start again, Brodlik.
BRODLIK: Start what again?
GILBROOK: I know there's Koteem on this planet. I feel it in my aching bones, Brodlik. And if it takes the rest of my miserable life, I shall not lay down and die until I make sure the filthy aliens have finally left us alone! You know something, Brodlik?
BRODLIK: What?
GILBROOK: My great-grandfather was just a kid working in the fields when it happened.
BRODLIK: When what happened?
GILBROOK: Fields. Can you imagine that? Huge areas of land where crops would grow. Crops that could feed thousands of people. And my great-granddad, he looked up into the sky and saw it and so he told his son, and so he told my dad, he saw that Koteem ship explode. He saw it. He said it was like paint spilling across a table. It seemed at first, he said, he said it was almost beautiful.
DELARPHIM: Pilot, what is that?
PILOT: An object has just appeared dead ahead of us. Cuboid, high mass and energy.
DELARPHIM: Full avoidance procedures. Emergency thrust.
PILOT: The object appears to be emitting some kind of warp distortion field.
DELARPHIM: But it is stationary.
PILOT: Captain, it has disappeared.
DELARPHIM: What is happening now?
PILOT: Toxin containers have smashed in the aft section.
DELARPHIM: What about the containment fields?
PILOT: You ordered them shut down. The hull is breaking up.
DELARPHIM: No!
KOTEEM: There was an accident in high orbit above Veln. Dyestrial waste was released. The ship was destroyed. The planet was terminally polluted. That was four Veln generations ago.
DOCTOR: As for making a difference, I don't really think we influenced anything at all.
GILBROOK: Beautiful.
